finding: The SNP rs17303202 in the RORA gene was associated with COVID-19 positive status (p=2.35E-5), hospitalized COVID-19 (p=2.76E-5), and COVID-19 with very severe respiratory symptoms (p=8.13E-4). This indicated a significant relationship between this variant and severe COVID-19 outcomes.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs4774377 located in the RORA gene showed association with laboratory-confirmed positive COVID-19 status (p=8.25E-5), underscoring its relevance to COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs341419 in the RORA gene was linked to COVID-19 with very severe respiratory symptoms (p=8.13E-4), pointing to its potential impact on severity in COVID-19 cases.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs12912196 in the RORA gene was associated with gene expression changes (p=3.9E-5), further indicating its functional relevance related to COVID-19.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs145719616 in the SLC12A6 gene was associated with COVID-19 (p=1.19E-4), suggesting that it plays a role in the disease dynamics.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs192235418 in the SLC12A6 gene exhibited association with hospitalized COVID-19 (p=4.42E-4), indicating its relevance to more severe forms of the disease.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs2705343 in the SLC12A6 gene showed association with COVID-19 with very severe respiratory symptoms (p=1.86E-3), highlighting its role in severe respiratory manifestations of the illness.
title: ACE2 Netlas: In-silico functional characterization and drug-gene interactions of ACE2 gene network to understand its potential involvement in COVID-19 susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs11073891 was identified for the first time as associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk, demonstrating a correlation with decreased uric acid levels in diabetic patients (P=0.03).
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs12898828 was found to be a novel susceptibility marker for T2D, with significant associations to the risk of the disease as determined through rigorous statistical analysis.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: rs12148357 was identified as an original marker associated with T2D risk, particularly linked to decreased expression levels of the AP3S2 gene in pancreatic tissue.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: This SNP was newly found to be linked to increased risk of T2D, especially in conjunction with other risk alleles, thus highlighting its role in the disease.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: rs7111 was recognized for the first time as a significant SNP associated with T2D, showing strong associations with several biochemical parameters.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: This SNP was newly associated with T2D risk and linked to higher fasting blood glucose levels in diabetes patients (P=0.017), marking it as an important genetic variant in the disease.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: This SNP was confirmed as a marker for T2D risk and was associated with expression levels of neighboring genes, including AP3S2, both in pancreatic and liver tissues.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: It was identified that individuals with the rs17240268-A/A genotype exhibited T2D 7.5 years earlier compared to other genotypes (P=0.023), linking this SNP to age of onset for the disease.
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: This SNP was associated with age of disease onset in females, where the G/G genotype was linked to developing T2D earlier than other genotypes (P=0.009).
title: The link between the ANPEP gene and type 2 diabetes mellitus may be mediated by the disruption of glutathione metabolism and redox homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs3784539, located intronic to CTSH on chromosome 15, showed a suggestive association with celiac disease with an initial p-value of 1.3 × 10^-5, and also surpassed the genome-wide significance threshold after conditional association with a p-value of 1.1 × 10^-8.
title: Joint analysis reveals shared autoimmune disease associations and identifies common mechanisms

finding: The SNP rs7181033 revealed another independent effect in celiac disease with a significant p-value of 8.7 × 10^-5, following the discovery of rs3784539.
title: Joint analysis reveals shared autoimmune disease associations and identifies common mechanisms

finding: SNP rs2412476 was implicated in associations with traits selected by TraitScan. Specifically, it was linked to insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), which is known to be upregulated in EWS, suggesting a role in the pathophysiology of EWS.
title: Subset scanning for multi-trait analysis using GWAS summary statistics

finding: This SNP was similarly found to be one of only two known loci identified within the DEPTH analysis, linking it to previously established CRC risk.
title: Using DEPendency of association on the number of Top Hits (DEPTH) as a complementary tool to identify novel risk loci in colorectal cancer

finding: The AAG insertion at rs142312981 was associated with lower expression of the FAH gene in former TB progressors but not in non-progressors in dendritic cells, indicating a specific regulatory impact linked to TB history.
title: History of tuberculosis disease is associated with genetic regulatory variation in Peruvians

finding: The variant rs7172038 exhibited significant regulatory effects within cardiomyocytes, particularly impacting activation of enhancer elements interacting with the promoter of HCN4, a gene crucial for atrial fibrillation (AF) risk. The two alternative alleles A and G of this SNP strongly reduced enhancer activation, correlating with decreased expression of HCN4 in experimental models.
title: Single-cell genomics improves the discovery of risk variants and genes of cardiac traits

finding: This SNP represented a novel finding in relation to cardiovascular traits, showing strong correlation in the EUR cohort.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: The rs1369031075 SNP found in the FRMD5 gene was associated with hospitalization with an odds ratio of 4.06, demonstrating its potential impact on disease severity.
title: Exome-wide association study to identify rare variants influencing COVID-19 outcomes: Results from the Host Genetics Initiative

finding: SPPL2A:rs59685680-G was noted to have a protective effect.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: The variant rs2036527 on chromosome 15 was associated with cigarettes per day in 32,389 African-American individuals, highlighting its relevance in smoking behaviour.
title: Genetic insights into smoking behaviours in 10,558 men of African ancestry from continental Africa and the UK

finding: Rs9646181 was previously associated with smoking trajectory contrast I in a trans-ethnic meta-analysis, where it was shown to be a significant marker for smoking behaviours, specifically linked to the gene SEMA6D.
title: Genetic insights into smoking behaviours in 10,558 men of African ancestry from continental Africa and the UK

finding: The intronic variant rs1036476 showed strong association with aortic valve regurgitation fraction, related to the FBN1 gene, highlighting its impact on connective tissue integrity.
title: Genetic architecture of cardiac dynamic flow volumes

finding: This SNP is associated with both the CHRNA3 and CHRNB4 genes and has been linked to nicotine dependence in prior studies. It was also found to be significant in the GWAS of GrimAge DNAm pack years.
title: Blood- and brain-based genome-wide association studies of smoking

finding: The SNP rs10152355 was positively associated with angina, showing an odds ratio (OR<sub>IVW</sub>) of 1.005 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) from 1.003 to 1.007, and a p-value of <0.001, suggesting a significant link between this genetic variant and the risk of angina.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: For atherosclerotic diseases, rs2642636 was positively associated with an OR<sub>IVW</sub> of 1.005, 95% CI ranging from 1.003 to 1.007, and a p-value <0.001, suggesting a genetic predisposition linked to atherosclerosis.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: For ischemic heart disease (IHD), rs12185072 was significantly associated, presenting an OR<sub>IVW</sub> of 1.004, with a 95% CI of 1.001 to 1.007 and a p-value of 0.005, marking its impact on IHD risk.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: SNP rs174418 was positively correlated with IHD, showing an OR<sub>IVW</sub> of 1.004 (95% CI: 1.001–1.007, p=0.005) emphasizing its relevance in heart disease susceptibility.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: This SNP was observed to be associated with myocardial infarction (MI), displaying an OR<sub>IVW</sub> of 1.001 (95% CI: 0.999–1.003, p=0.199), although the finding was less statistically significant.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The rs3865014 variant in the GLCE gene was associated with body mass index (BMI), blood hemoglobin levels, hypertension, and cerebrovascular events in the TAMRISK study, underscoring its role in determining various metabolic and cardiovascular traits.
title: Variability in proteoglycan biosynthetic genes reveals new facets of heparan sulfates diversity. A systematic review and analysis

finding: The variant rs2036527 was noted as the top-ranked variant for creatinine-standardized total nicotine equivalents (TNE) and was significantly associated with cigarettes per day (CPD) and lung cancer in African Americans, with a result of β = 0.57 and P = 1.4E-5, highlighting its role in smoking-related phenotypes.
title: Multiethnic Prediction of Nicotine Biomarkers and Association with Nicotine Dependence

finding: The rs55676755 variant was trained in all penalized regression models for TNE and showed significant associations with pulmonary disease. This highlighted its predictive capacity regarding the exposure to smoking-related toxicants across various ethnicities.
title: Multiethnic Prediction of Nicotine Biomarkers and Association with Nicotine Dependence

finding: The lead variant for locus 4, rs35859241, showed a significant association with a p-value of 3.69 × 10^−8. It served as an eQTL for SCG3 and GLDN in brain tissue, indicating its potential involvement in gene regulation associated with RTV.
title: Genome-wide association study in 404,302 individuals identifies 7 significant loci for reaction time variability

finding: The SNP rs2606134 was associated with the 5' untranslated region of SCG3 and had a CADD score of 13.15, indicating biological relevance. It was in linkage disequilibrium with rs35859241 in locus 4, reinforcing its significance in gene regulation impacting RTV.
title: Genome-wide association study in 404,302 individuals identifies 7 significant loci for reaction time variability

finding: The SNP rs7183733 served as the primary cis-pQTL for CA12, which was linked to dentures. An MR analysis employing CA12 levels (as the exposure) and dentures (as the outcome) demonstrated that CA12 levels could impact denture use with an odds ratio of 1.12, a 95% confidence interval of 1.08-1.16, and a p-value of 5.59e-12, indicating a clear causal relationship.
title: Identification of therapeutic targets for 18 clinical diseases by integrating human plasma proteome with genome

finding: The pathogenic variant p.R82C in RAB27A, associated with hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) (OMIM number 267700), was found to have an AF of 0.5% in the Qatari population and 2.7% in the Arab and Bedouin subpopulations, while absent in 1000 Genome and having a very low frequency in gnomAD V2. This variant was significantly enriched in the Qatari population compared to global datasets.
title: Genetic landscape of rare autoinflammatory disease variants in Qatar and Middle Eastern populations through the integration of whole-genome and exome datasets

finding: The SNP rs4702 was associated with schizophrenia through the downregulation of FURIN expression by miR-338-3p, which in turn reduced BDNF production. This finding highlighted the potential mechanism by which the G allele of rs4702 could affect neurodevelopmental processes related to psychiatric conditions.
title: Altered gene expression and PTSD symptom dimensions in World Trade Center responders

finding: The SNP rs16969968 was associated with brain reactivity in nicotine-dependent women when exposed to smoking images. This finding suggested that genetic variation in the CHRNA5 gene could influence the neurobiological response to smoking cues, a significant aspect in understanding substance use disorders and cue reactivity in fMRI studies.
title: A Methodological Checklist for fMRI Drug Cue Reactivity Studies: Development and Expert Consensus

finding: The obesity-related PLIN1 gene polymorphism rs1052700 influenced the interaction between meal timing and weight loss. Specifically, AA carriers who ate lunch late experienced less weight loss than those who ate early, whereas TT carriers did not show any influence of meal timing on weight loss. This finding suggested a significant role of this SNP in dietary behavior and weight management.
title: Circadian meal timing is heritable and associated with insulin sensitivity

finding: SNP rs6224, located in intron 13 of the FURIN gene, exhibited colocalization with both SCZ and BIP GWAS loci. This variant was in moderate linkage disequilibrium with rs4702, a validated eQTL for FURIN's expression, indicating its role in neuropsychiatric disorder risk through gene expression modulation.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: The SNP rs4702, located in the 3’-UTR of the FURIN gene, has been documented as an eQTL. It was shown to be significantly associated with reduced expression of FURIN, linking it to neurodevelopmental risks in neuropsychiatric disorders related to SCZ.
title: Cross-ancestry, cell-type-informed atlas of gene, isoform, and splicing regulation in the developing human brain

finding: The rs2251086 variant at the VPS13C locus was found to have high PAR estimates across all populations studied in relation to Parkinson's disease, suggesting its widespread impact.
title: Multi-ancestry population attributable risk assessment of common genetic variation in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases

finding: The variant rs58365910 near CHRNA5 showed a suggestive association with LA cancer, with clear interaction effects noted specifically amongst smokers.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs1051730 SNP in the CHRNA3 gene was associated with a significantly increased risk of COPD in ever smokers, with an odds ratio of 7.15 (95% CI: 4.73-10.8, P=9.3×10^-21). In contrast, there was no evidence of a causal association between rs1051730 and IPF, where the odds ratio was 0.45 (95% CI: 0.06-3.28, P=0.43). This indicated that while smoking was causally linked to COPD, the association with IPF was limited, suggesting the need to consider other environmental factors in IPF.
title: A Mendelian randomisation study of smoking causality in IPF compared with COPD

finding: SNP rs4702 was previously associated with OUD and was confirmed in this study as a significant exonic variant in the FURIN gene.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: The single nucleotide polymorphism rs16969968, found on the nicotine receptor gene CHRNA5, was examined in the context of maternal smoking. It correlated with the number of cigarettes smoked per day, indicating that an increase in the number of risk alleles (A/T, with A as the risk allele) was associated with higher smoking intensity. Analysis revealed that children with two copies of the risk allele had mothers with higher smoking rates compared to those with zero copies, especially noticeable until the mid-1950s when the trends began to converge due to potential declining sample sizes.
title: The prevalence, trends and heterogeneity in maternal smoking around birth between the 1930s and 1970s

finding: The homozygous nonsense mutation c.581_582delTT (p.Phe194*) was identified in patient F3/II-2 through whole-exome sequencing (WES) analysis. This mutation had an allele frequency of 8 × 10^-6 in the ExAC database and was predicted to be pathogenic. The same variant was also detected in another patient (F4/II-2), confirming its association with Bloom syndrome (BS).
title: Phenotypic distinctions of BLM- and RMI1-associated Bloom syndrome

finding: A homozygous missense variant c.3164G>C (p.Cys1055Ser) was identified in two siblings (F5-II/2 and F5-II/3) whose parents were heterozygous carriers. This variant, located in exon 16 of the BLM gene, had an allele frequency of 17 × 10^-6 and was implicated in the pathogenesis of BS due to its location on the well-conserved RecQ domain, which is critical for the enzymatic activity of the BLM protein.
title: Phenotypic distinctions of BLM- and RMI1-associated Bloom syndrome

finding: The rs113298164 variant, p.Thr405Met in the LIPC gene, was associated with higher serum apoA-1 levels (p=7.8×10^-8). In heterozygous carriers, the median serum apoA-1 level was 163 mg/dl compared to 138 mg/dl in non-carriers. However, this SNP was not significantly associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) or stroke risk.
title: Novel protein-altering variants associated with serum apolipoprotein and lipid levels

finding: The rs3829462 variant, p.Phe368Leu in LIPC, was associated with higher apoA-1 levels (p=0.02). This finding corroborated previous studies indicating its potential impact on serum lipid levels.
title: Novel protein-altering variants associated with serum apolipoprotein and lipid levels

finding: The rs121912502 variant, p.Ser301Phe in LIPC, was nominally associated with apoA-1 levels despite low imputation quality (p=0.04), suggesting a potential influence on serum lipid levels.
title: Novel protein-altering variants associated with serum apolipoprotein and lipid levels

finding: The SNP rs2472297, located 13kb upstream of CYP1A2, was reported to have a significant association with clozapine plasma concentrations, suggesting its potential regulatory role in clozapine metabolism.
title: Rare Variants in Pharmacogenes Influence Clozapine Metabolism in Individuals with Schizophrenia

finding: Identified in the context of <italic>THBS1</italic>, this SNP was recognized for its association with DMD modifier effects from previous studies and was confirmed as a significant modifier in the current analysis.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of loss of ambulation in dystrophinopathy patients suggests multiple candidate modifiers of disease severity

finding: Variant rs55707100, linked to gene MAP1A, had a statistically significant P-value of 2.61×10^-15, associating it with heart failure, which suggests a role of MAP1A in this condition.
title: Exploring novel risk loci for heart failure and the shared genetic etiology with blood lipids, blood pressure, and blood glucose: a large-scale multi-trait association analysis

finding: The SNP rs12917449 was associated with type 2 diabetes, providing insight into its genetic influence on this specific metabolic disorder.
title: Exploiting collider bias to apply two-sample summary data Mendelian randomization methods to one-sample individual level data

finding: The SNP rs1847325 in the CERS3 gene was significantly associated with increased brain glucose metabolism in the bilateral frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes, which was measured through voxel-wise analysis of FDG-PET imaging, suggesting a link to Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Multi-Omic Analyses Characterize the Ceramide/Sphingomyelin Pathway as a Therapeutic Target in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The variant rs11852372 was linked to higher protein levels and was associated positively with lung cancer (LC) through multiple analyses, including the UK's Pharma Proteomics Project.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: The SNP rs12914385 showed similar positive associations with elevated protein levels and was also linked to lung cancer (LC) in the context of the identified pQTL associations.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: This variant was associated with higher levels of CTSH protein in plasma and demonstrated a positive correlation with lung cancer (LC) findings.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: An association in cis of rs12901653 in CHD2 with cumulative prenatal stress was identified for DNAm at the nearby cg24317086 site. The association was significant (B=-0.026, SE=0.003, p=4.07×10^-16), linking prenatal stress to DNAm changes that relate to CHD2 Adjacent Suppressive Regulatory RNA.
title: Interactive effects of genotype with prenatal stress on DNA methylation at birth

finding: The SNP rs528350911, located within a putative enhancer region associated with the ONECUT1 gene, showed a strong association with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and other glycemic traits. Specifically, it indicated a statistically significant relationship with random glucose levels and T2D adjusted for BMI, with odds ratios of 1.31. This variant was found to be situated at the binding sites of key pancreas-specific transcription factors like PDX1, NKX6.1, and ONECUT1, emphasizing its relevance in pancreatic development and insulin secretion impairment.
title: A ONECUT1 regulatory, non-coding region in pancreatic development and diabetes

finding: The SNP rs2229961 was associated with lung cancer and identified at the 15q25.1 locus, known for its implications in smoking behaviors.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The SNP rs8192479 was noted to be associated with lung cancer at the 15q25.1 locus, linked with smoking propensity.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The SNP rs151118057 was included in the associations found at the 15q25.1 locus related to lung cancer susceptibility.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The SNP rs12441817 was linked to lung cancer susceptibility and associated with expression of CYP1A1 at the 15q24 locus.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The SNP rs72740955 was reported as a significant variant at the 15q25 locus, related to lung cancer susceptibility.
title: Genetic analysis of lung cancer reveals novel susceptibility loci and germline impact on somatic mutation burden

finding: The variant rs16969968 was acknowledged as a functional variant associated with smoking heaviness, indicating that individuals inheriting this allele were likely to smoke one more cigarette per day per risk allele. This association highlighted its role in influencing smoking behavior and was relevant in the context of understanding nicotine dependence.
title: A multivariable Mendelian randomisation study exploring the direct effects of nicotine on health compared with the other constituents of tobacco smoke: Implications for e-cigarette use

finding: The genetic variant rs10851907 was identified as the main variant in the cotinine genome-wide association study (GWAS). However, it was noted to be in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs16969968, which contributed to its weakness as a proxy for nicotine exposure in Mendelian randomization analyses. This finding underlined the complexities in differentiating the direct effects of nicotine from smoking heaviness.
title: A multivariable Mendelian randomisation study exploring the direct effects of nicotine on health compared with the other constituents of tobacco smoke: Implications for e-cigarette use

finding: The SNP rs17239735 was found to have a genome-wide significant interaction with APOE ε2, where its effect on AD risk was inversely related in ε2 carriers compared to those with ε3/ε3 or ε3/ε4 genotypes.
title: Protein phosphatase 2A, complement component 4, and APOE genotype linked to Alzheimer’s disease using a systems biology approach

finding: The SNP rs12906125 was statistically prioritized as the most likely causal variant for hypertension and coronary artery disease (CAD) at the <italic>FES</italic> locus. It was noted for being a stronger expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for <italic>FES</italic> than the nearby gene <italic>FURIN</italic>.
title: Association analyses of predicted loss-of-function variants prioritized 15 genes as blood pressure regulators

finding: The SNP rs11634680 was found to be suggestively associated with John Henryism (JH), replicating findings from a prior study that reported a similar odds ratio (OR of 0.71 to 0.74) and comparable P-values (3.3×10−7 to 6.2×10−7). This suggests a consistent relationship between this SNP and lower levels of vulnerability associated with JH.
title: Genome-wide association study of John Henryism in the CARDIA Cohort suggests a molecular mechanism behind lower nicotine addiction rates

finding: Prioritized through fine-mapping, rs4702 interacted with the FURIN gene, and its associated risk allele was shown to decrease FURIN expression, impacting neuronal function.
title: Fine-mapping genomic loci refines bipolar disorder risk genes

finding: The rs71401691 variant at the chr15q24.2 locus was significantly associated with hospitalization in women (OR 1.23; P=4.72×10⁻⁸) but not in men.
title: A year of COVID-19 GWAS results from the GRASP portal reveals potential SARS-CoV-2 modifiers

finding: Linked to CYP19A1, this SNP was noted for its involvement in large joint osteoarthritis through expected aromatase inhibition effects.
title: Investigation of the genetic architecture of cam morphology, and its relationship with hip osteoarthritis, using alpha angle as a proxy measure

finding: The SNP rs916977 was associated with the fractal dimension (D_f) of retinal vasculature, showing a significant relationship with pigmentation and coronary artery disease (CAD). Its strong association indicated a common genetic basis underlying these traits.
title: Decreased retinal vascular complexity is an early biomarker of MI supported by a shared genetic control

finding: The SNP rs12913832 displayed a highly significant association with D_f and was linked to pigmentation traits and cardiovascular outcomes, confirming its role in the genetic control of retinal vasculature related to CAD.
title: Decreased retinal vascular complexity is an early biomarker of MI supported by a shared genetic control

finding: The SNP rs2521501 showed robust evidence for association with hypertension, supporting a nearby gene (FES) that involved in pathways related to hypertension risk, although its precise influence was unclear.
title: Analysis of 200,000 exome-sequenced UK Biobank subjects implicates genes involved in increased and decreased risk of hypertension

finding: The intergenic variant between HCN4 and REC114 identified a rare variant in HCN4 associated with increased AF risk, reinforcing its connection to cardiac electrical activity.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The missense variant in PITX2 was associated with increased risk of AF, highlighting its transcriptional regulatory role in cardiac rhythm.
title: Genetic associations of protein-coding variants in human disease

finding: The SNP rs1979409 in the NEO1 locus was significantly associated with the occurrence of left common trunk pulmonary veins (LCT-PVs) in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF). This finding was corroborated by a higher polygenic risk score (PRS) in patients with LCT-PVs compared to those with normal pulmonary veins, with a statistically significant result (p=1.64e-05).
title: Left common trunkus pulmonary veins have genetic background and poorer rhythm outcome after paroxysmal atrial fibrillation catheter ablation

finding: Also recognized as a significant SNP in the context of ocular disease association, contributing to the network of genetic risk factors for age-related ocular disorders.
title: Genome-wide analysis of genetic pleiotropy and causal genes across three age-related ocular disorders

finding: The variant rs2043085 was positively associated with lipid species in the BHS cohort, reinforcing its importance in lipid-wide associations and its relevance in the context of coronary artery disease.
title: Comprehensive genetic analysis of the human lipidome identifies novel loci controlling lipid homeostasis with links to coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs3865014 (A>G) was linked to various health conditions including BMI, blood hemoglobin levels, hypertension, and cerebrovascular events in the TAMRISK study, underscoring its importance in multiple metabolic and cardiovascular health outcomes.
title: Genetic variability in proteoglycan biosynthetic genes reveals new facets of heparan sulfates diversity. A systematic review and analysis

finding: The SNP rs3825807, which encodes a p.Ser214Pro variant in the ADAMTS7 gene, was found to confer a significantly reduced risk of incident coronary artery disease (CAD) among never smokers (HR: 0.89; 95% CI: 0.84–0.93; p=1.1 × 10−5). This protective effect was not observed in ever smokers. Additionally, the same SNP was associated with a significantly increased risk of pneumonia among ever smokers (HR: 1.08; 95% CI: 1.03–1.12; p=4.4 × 10−4), revealing an interaction between smoking status and the variant's effect on disease risk.
title: Genome-wide pleiotropy analysis of coronary artery disease and pneumonia identifies shared immune pathways

finding: The SNP rs55781567 at the 15q25.1 locus related to the CHRNA5 gene demonstrated higher frequencies and larger effects in the white population, reinforcing its role as a smoking-related genetic risk locus for lung cancer.
title: Ethnic differences of genetic risk and smoking in lung cancer: two prospective cohort studies

finding: The SNP rs4702, located in the 3' UTR of the FURIN gene, was successfully fine-mapped by SuSiEx. It was previously reported as a causal variant, and while it did not reach genome-wide significance in the EAS population (P = 1.06E-3), SuSiEx indicated a strong likelihood that it was shared between EUR and EAS populations, with causal probabilities of 1.000 and 0.976 respectively.
title: Fine-mapping across diverse ancestries drives the discovery of putative causal variants underlying human complex traits and diseases

finding: This SNP was found to be significantly associated with coffee and caffeine intake, linking it to the intergenic region between CYP1A1 and CYP1A2, which are involved in xenobiotic metabolism. It was associated with various traits including alcohol consumption, clozapine pharmacokinetics, and kidney function.
title: Genome-Wide Association Studies of Coffee Intake in UK/US Participants of European Ancestry Uncover Gene-Cohort Influences

finding: The T allele was associated with reduced ADAMTS7 mRNA expression levels, leading to a 12% reduced risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) for smokers and a 5% reduced risk for those who have smoked. This indicated that smoking reversed the T allele's protective effect, illustrating the gene-by-environment (GxE) interaction that contributed to phenotypic heterogeneity.
title: Improving Genetic Association Studies with a Novel Methodology that Unveils the Hidden Complexity of All-Cause Heart Failure

finding: Within AD-FBS families, the damaging missense variant in <italic>SPPL2A</italic> (chr15:50716490:T:C) fully co-segregated with the common variant, suggesting its relevance in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease.
title: Identification of Rare Damaging Missense and Loss of Function Variants in GWAS Loci Using Genome Sequencing Data from Two Cohorts of Familial Late-Onset Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The damaging missense variant in <italic>ADAM10</italic> (chr15:58753575:A:G) was identified as co-segregating with common variants in EFIGA families, reinforcing its possible connection to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Identification of Rare Damaging Missense and Loss of Function Variants in GWAS Loci Using Genome Sequencing Data from Two Cohorts of Familial Late-Onset Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The study indicated that carriers of the A-allele of the SELENOS -105G/A promoter polymorphism (rs28665122) experienced increased endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and higher production of inflammatory cytokines. This finding was contextually significant as it showed that the down-regulation of selenoproteins SELENOF, SELENOM, SELENOK, and SELENOS by SARS-CoV-2 could potentially lead to a cytokine storm in susceptible individuals, thereby linking this SNP to severity in COVID-19 pathology.
title: SARS-CoV-2 suppresses mRNA expression of selenoproteins associated with ferroptosis, endoplasmic reticulum stress and DNA synthesis

finding: Moderate selection was inferred for rs12913832 in the OCA2/HERC2 gene with an estimated s of about 0.002. This SNP is causal for blue-brown eye color and was suggested to have begun selection at least 50 kya.
title: An approximate full-likelihood method for inferring selection and allele frequency trajectories from DNA sequence data

finding: The SNP rs16969968 in the CHRNA5 gene was studied in the context of its effects on neuronal excitability and morphology. Neurons carrying this SNP exhibited morphological changes similar to those seen in alpha5 knockout rats, primarily showing longer apical dendrites that extended into superficial cortical layers. Moreover, while L6 RS neurons in the rs16969968 group did not show significant differences in electrophysiological properties compared to wild-type rats, the studies indicated that this genetic variant could influence synaptic plasticity and cognitive deficits, potentially linking it to psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia and nicotine dependence.
title: Linking Altered Neuronal and Synaptic Properties to Nicotinic Receptor Alpha5 Subunit Gene Dysfunction: A Translational Investigation in Rat mPFC and Human Cortical Layer 6

finding: The SNP rs12101693 was originally identified in the study by Bendel et al. (2020), which reported its significance in the detection of Grapevine Leafroll-Associated Virus 1 and 3 in grapevines using hyperspectral imaging. This finding demonstrated the importance of utilizing molecular data in conjunction with remote sensing technologies to improve disease management in viticulture.
title: Assessing the capacity of high-resolution commercial satellite imagery for grapevine downy mildew detection and surveillance in New York state

finding: The non-coding SMAD3 variant (rs8040709) was identified as a centenarian-enriched intronic variant that altered the binding of ELK1, leading to reduced SMAD3 expression, which in turn contributed to decreased senescence and inflammation in endothelial cells.
title: Longevity-associated SMAD3 non-coding centenarian variant impairs a cell-type specific enhancer to reduce inflammation

finding: The variant rs8040749 was prioritized as a potential causal variant for its role in creating a binding site for the ETS family transcription factors, enhancing ELK1's binding, which subsequently reduced SMAD3 expression and contributed to human longevity.
title: Longevity-associated SMAD3 non-coding centenarian variant impairs a cell-type specific enhancer to reduce inflammation

finding: The rs2168518 SNP was associated with increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease and linked with cancer risks across populations. It appeared within related studies focusing on gene expression variability.
title: Signatures of genetic variation in human microRNAs point to processes of positive selection related to population-specific disease risks

finding: The SNP rs79305633 was linked to multiple clinical conditions including microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism (OMIM #210720) and epileptic encephalopathy. Its association was highlighted due to its characteristics of prenatal brain development issues.
title: Derived Homo sapiens cis-eQTL regulation: implications for brain evolution

finding: The rs4702 SNP was associated with a G allele-specific downregulation of FURIN expression, which was mediated by the microRNA miR-338-3p. This downregulation resulted in a reduction of Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) production, highlighting its relevance in schizophrenia phenotypes.
title: The kpc-1 3’UTR facilitates dendritic transport and translation of mRNAs for dendrite arborization of a mechanosensory neuron important for male courtship

finding: The SNP rs1426654 was noted as the lowest-cost characteristic SNP for the third split in the tangles tree, which distinguished between European (EUR) and South Asian (SAS) populations. It is associated with traits such as iris color and skin pigmentation in South Asians.
title: Inferring Ancestry with the Hierarchical Soft Clustering Approach tangleGen

finding: There was a strong association found between rs2033939 at 15q14 and both cortical thickness (CTh) and cortical volume (CV) in the postcentral cortex, with discovery p-values being extraordinarily low (p<sub>Discovery,</sub> <sub>CTh</sub>=1.17×10<sup>-73</sup> and p<sub>Discovery,</sub> <sub>CV</sub>=4.34×10<sup>-133</sup>). This suggested significant genetic influence on brain structure within this region.
title: Genetic Determinants of Cortical Structure (Thickness, Surface Area and Volumes) among Disease Free Adults in the CHARGE Consortium

finding: The association of rs1080066 at 15q14 with cortical surface area (CSA) was significantly strong (p<sub>Discovery,</sub> <sub>CSA</sub>=8.45×10<sup>-109</sup>) in the precentral cortex, indicating genetic contributions to cortical structures that are implicated in motor functions.
title: Genetic Determinants of Cortical Structure (Thickness, Surface Area and Volumes) among Disease Free Adults in the CHARGE Consortium

finding: The SNP rs11071010 was associated with increased expression of aldehyde dehydrogenase 1A3 (ALDH1A3) in a breast cancer context. This relationship was significant in the murine xenograft tumor model, where human-specific GAPDH RT-qPCR revealed that the expression of ALDH1A3 led to enhanced lung metastasis of MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells implanted in NOD/SCID mice. This finding supported the role of the SNP in mediating metastatic behavior in cancer, contributing to understanding metastasis in human cancers.
title: Human-specific GAPDH RT-qPCR is an accurate and sensitive method of xenograft metastasis quantification

finding: Part of a significant modifier effect in the FAN1 region (15AM1) that also showed links to increased somatic expansion.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: This missense variant was associated with increased somatic expansion (15AM3), contributing to the correlation with the clinical GWAS outcomes.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: Linked with the FAN1 region as a distinct significant marker associated with the increase in expansion (15AM5, conditioned p=5.7E-07).
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: This eQTL SNP exhibited increased FAN1 expression, showing distinct patterns linked to somatic expansion behavior.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: This SNP was correlated with increased FAN1 expression and identified in association with expansion regulation.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs8031627 was a positive original finding linked to the exon-intron-ratio of SMAD3, a transcription factor involved in the transforming growth factor-beta signaling pathway, and colocalized with GWAS variants for lung function trait FVC.
title: Disentangling genetic effects on transcriptional and post-transcriptional gene regulation through integrating exon and intron expression QTLs

finding: SNP rs4778055, which is linked to the novel long non-coding RNA ENSG00000258922, was classified under the induced category for G×T interactions, providing evidence of altered genotype effect patterns as supported by all three modeling approaches.
title: Probabilistic classification of gene-by-treatment interactions on molecular count phenotypes

finding: At the SLC24A5 locus (rs1426654), also linked to skin pigmentation, strong selection occurred earlier than the SLC45A2 locus, reaching near fixation approximately 3,500 years ago.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: The SNP rs11071720, located within the 3rd intron of the TPM1 gene, was in strong linkage disequilibrium with rs3809566. It was associated with reduced TPM1 expression and linked to higher platelet count and lower MPV among carriers of the minor allele.
title: Machine learning-based identification and cellular validation of Tropomyosin 1 as a genetic inhibitor of hematopoiesis

finding: The high-scoring SNP rs4075583 was associated with decreased TPM1 expression and was linked to alterations in platelet physiology, although this association was not confirmed in GTEx tissues.
title: Machine learning-based identification and cellular validation of Tropomyosin 1 as a genetic inhibitor of hematopoiesis

finding: The rs12913832 SNP was identified as a modulator of human pigmentation, specifically by decreasing chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding related to pigmentation suggests that variations in this SNP affect the regulation of genes involved in melanin production, thereby contributing to the phenotypic expression of traits such as skin and hair color.
title: Loss of MC1R signaling implicates TBX3 in pheomelanogenesis and melanoma predisposition

finding: This SNP was associated with the gene expression of TERF2IP in a manner where the risk allele had a stronger effect in males than females, indicating a potential protective mechanism for lower expression in the context of CAD.
title: Genetic regulation of human aortic smooth muscle cell gene expression and splicing predict causal coronary artery disease genes

finding: The SNP rs117799466 was linked to SLC12A6, where it increased binding affinities for several repressive transcription factors. This enhanced binding may contribute to the downregulation of SLC12A6, a gene associated with potassium uptake impairments in schizophrenia.
title: Unveiling causal regulatory mechanisms through cell-state parallax

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was associated with modulation of human pigmentation. This finding indicated that the SNP influenced the conformation of chromatin loops between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter, thereby affecting gene expression related to pigmentation traits.
title: Common DNA sequence variation influences 3-dimensional conformation of the human genome

finding: The allele at rs1426654 in the SLC24A5 gene was found to be at higher frequencies in populations like Altai_MLBA and Chandman_IA, contrasting with its frequency in groups with higher Eastern Eurasian ancestry, suggesting a historical differentiation influenced by ancestry.
title: A dynamic 6,000-year genetic history of Eurasia’s Eastern Steppe

finding: The SNP rs16942341[T] was found to be associated with decreased height, with an effect size of -0.13 SD and a p-value of 4·10−27, in a large GWAS analysis comprising 183,000 individuals of European descent. In the present study, it was reported that the synonymous SNP showed a strong association with height (effect = -0.13 SD, p = 1.02·10−10). The finding was correlated with the 5-motif deletion of a SV in the <italic>ACAN</italic> gene.
title: Long read sequencing of 3,622 Icelanders provides insight into the role of structural variants in human diseases and other traits

finding: The SNP rs3809508 was associated with the risk of obesity in the HELENA study, highlighting the influence of maternal educational level on this association. This finding suggested that the neuromedin B (NMB) gene polymorphism might play a role in obesity predisposition, potentially affecting appetite control and feeding preference.
title: Neuropeptide Neuromedin B does not alter body weight and glucose homeostasis nor does it act as an insulin-releasing peptide

finding: The germline variant rs34988193, located in the ANKDD1a gene, was found to cause an amino acid change from lysine to glutamate and was predictive of poor prognosis in two independent datasets (TCGA and CGGA), with a hazard ratio of 1.73 (p=0.001) in TCGA. This variant was predicted to be within the top 0.06% of deleterious mutations, with significant conservation of the wild type residue across species.
title: The Germline Variants rs61757955 and rs34988193 are Predictive of Survival in Low Grade Glioma Patients

finding: The LIPC-related SNP rs10468017 was associated with hypercholesterolemia, underscoring its role in lipid abnormalities.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The SNP rs3759916 was associated with schizophrenia risk and influenced the promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene. It was part of a non-risk haplotype (CGC-type) that underwent positive selection mainly in Asia over approximately 20–30 millennia, adapted to psychosocial stress.
title: Lower promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene has been favored in evolving human collective brains

finding: The SNP rs3759915 was linked to schizophrenia risk and played a role in the promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene. It contributed to the prevalence of the TCT-type in non-African populations and was part of the positive selection of the CGC-type haplotype associated with reduced schizophrenia risk.
title: Lower promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene has been favored in evolving human collective brains

finding: The SNP rs3759914 was also associated with schizophrenia risk and contributed to the promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene. Its inclusion in the positive selection of the CGC-type emphasized the genetic adaptation to environmental psychosocial stress.
title: Lower promoter activity of the ST8SIA2 gene has been favored in evolving human collective brains

finding: The association of rs10046 in the CYP19A1 gene with Alzheimer's disease risk was highlighted in a systematic review involving 11,051 subjects.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1143704 polymorphism in the CYP19A1 gene was found to be associated with the risk of Alzheimer’s disease according to systematic review findings.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: An association was reported for the rs767199 polymorphism in CYP19A1 and Alzheimer's disease risk in the meta-analysis that included over 11,000 subjects.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs727479 polymorphism in the CYP19A1 gene was included in findings indicating its association with increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: Research indicated that the rs1065778 polymorphism in CYP19A1 was associated with Alzheimer's disease risk, as supported by a meta-analysis.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1062033 polymorphism was evaluated in the context of assessing Alzheimer's disease risk and found to have relevant associations.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs1008805 SNP in the CYP19A1 gene was determined to have a significant connection to Alzheimer's disease risk in the aggregated data.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The rs700519 polymorphism was included among several associations found between aromatase (CYP19A1) gene polymorphisms and Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Identification of Key Pathways and Genes in Dementia via Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The LIPC-related SNP rs10468017 was associated with hypercholesterolemia, reflecting its role in lipid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma lipids

finding: The SNP rs11072494 was part of a group of variants linked to congenital craniofacial abnormalities, specifically cleft palate and cleft lip. This variant was associated with several <italic>trans</italic>-eGenes that are involved in biological pathways related to JNK and MAPK cascades, which are implicated in the aforementioned abnormalities.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs2289187, along with three other SNPs, was linked to congenital craniofacial abnormalities. It showed associations with six downstream <italic>trans</italic>-eGenes and was indicative of influences on critical biological processes like the JNK and MAPK cascades.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs10459648 was identified as part of the same set of variants linked to congenital craniofacial abnormalities. It was associated with significant downstream <italic>trans</italic>-eGene connections and implicated in relevant developmental processes.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs6495117 was also part of the variants associated with congenital craniofacial abnormalities. It linked to multiple <italic>trans</italic>-eGenes that were significantly involved in biological pathways related to the observed craniofacial features.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The SNP rs6224 exhibited the strongest association with surface area (SA) in schizophrenia (SCZ) with a harmonic mean p-value (HMP) of 3.66×10<sup>-8</sup>, indicating a significant genetic correlation with brain structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: This SNP showed increased thickness in CT in SCZ, emphasizing its neurogenetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: Stable associations with SCZ—this SNP was identified as linking to increased CT in key areas.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: In the context of breast and ovarian cancer, rs8028409 was found to be associated with decreased RCCD1 expression, where the A (risk) allele correlated with lower expression levels. This SNP was identified as part of the credible causal set of 17 risk variants associated with both cancers, with significance levels reaching P<sub>breast</sub> = 4.73 x 10<sup>-15</sup> and P<sub>ovarian</sub> = 3.26 x 10<sup>-7</sup>.
title: Transcriptome and interactome analyses identify the TP53 interacting gene RCCD1 as a candidate susceptibility gene at the 15p26.1 breast and ovarian cancer risk locus

finding: Similar to rs8028409, rs8037137 was implicated in susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancer, showing an association with decreased RCCD1 expression. The T (risk) allele was linked to lower expression levels in both cancers, with statistically significant P<sub>breast</sub> = 6.52 x 10<sup>-15</sup> and P<sub>ovarian</sub> = 4.61 x 10<sup>-7</sup>. It was also included in the credible causal set of 17 risk variants.
title: Transcriptome and interactome analyses identify the TP53 interacting gene RCCD1 as a candidate susceptibility gene at the 15p26.1 breast and ovarian cancer risk locus

finding: The SNP rs17293632 was identified as an important modifier of the risk of myocardial infarction. This single nucleotide variant lies within a functional smooth muscle enhancer and influences smooth muscle cell differentiation and proliferation through its interaction with other transcription factors that are critical to smooth muscle biology and coronary artery disease (CAD) risk. Although its exact effects on plaque biology were noted to be unclear, it was established that SMAD3 modifies these biological processes.
title: Smad3 Regulates Smooth Muscle Cell Fate and Governs Adverse Remodeling and Calcification of Atherosclerotic Plaque

finding: This SNP, linked to the genes IL16 and STARD5, was associated with a significant upregulation of transposable element (TE) family expression in lymphoblastoid cell lines. It indicated the potential regulatory role of IL16 and STARD5 in L1 RNA control, implicating these genes in processes related to cellular senescence and genome stability.
title: An eQTL-based Approach Reveals Candidate Regulators of LINE-1 RNA Levels in Lymphoblastoid Cells

finding: At the Crohn's disease and asthma-associated 15q22.33 locus, rs17293632 was a monocyte caQTL with significant effects linked to multiple SMAD3 isoform promoters.
title: Mapping genetic effects on cell type-specific chromatin accessibility and annotating complex trait variants using single nucleus ATAC-seq

finding: This SNP was linked to asymmetries in regional connectivity with a z-score of 7.11, notably associated with connectivity of the rolandic operculum.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This SNP, in high LD with rs28520337, was previously associated with cortical surface area.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This lead SNP in LOXL1 was significant for retaining connections with pseudoexfoliative glaucoma and thereby indirectly related to retinal detachment risks.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The rs8028374 (A/G) variant was mapped as a puQTL associated with the external promoters of the TTC23 gene, with a very significant P-value of 6.99 x 10^-18 and a beta coefficient of -0.56. This finding was corroborated by the results of the CAGE-based puQTL analysis.
title: Mapping of promoter usage QTL using RNA-seq data reveals their contributions to complex traits

finding: As one of the top causal SNPs for FURIN expression, rs4702 was confirmed as a significant positive control. This SNP exhibited significant transcriptional shifts, affirming its relevance in the context of genetic risk associated with brain disorders.
title: Dynamic stress- and inflammatory-based regulation of psychiatric risk loci in human neurons

finding: Though previously suggested as a signal of selection, this SNP reached genome-wide significance in this study, highlighting its evolutionary implications.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: The SNP rs17228058 was found to be associated with IBD in the context of a fine-mapping study, linking it to differential DNA methylation as part of a mQTL. The study highlighted its relevance in understanding genetic predisposition to IBD.
title: The DNA Methylome of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) reflects intrinsic and extrinsic factors in intestinal epithelial cells

finding: For SNP rs1800414, spiking at lower concentrations was noted due to its originally low concentration resulting in a heterozygous genotype call. This seemed to correlate to the broader observation of high no-call rates across SNPs, likely attributed to interference and insufficient amplification, but confirmed that manipulated SNPs could lead to altered outcomes.
title: Doctoring Direct-to-Consumer Genetic Tests with DNA Spike-Ins

finding: The SNP rs4932178 was identified as a primary driver in model predictions for coronary artery disease (CAD) cases, residing in a putative enhancer for PRC1 and within the promoter of FURIN, a gene whose expression affects endothelial function important in CAD pathophysiology.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs113028686, located in the 5'-UTR of PRC1, was linked to the CAD phenotype and shown to be an eQTL for FES in various tissues, contributing significantly to model predictions across multiple CAD clusters.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs11073964, identified as a missense mutation for VPS33B, was part of a novel set of loci associated with early-onset myocardial infarction and was linked to the CAD phenotype.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The SNP rs17636091, which is intronic in PRC1, was indicated as a key driver of predictions in multiple CAD clusters, reflecting its potential significance in disease modeling.
title: Genetic analysis of coronary artery disease using tree-based automated machine learning informed by biology-based feature selection

finding: The schizophrenia risk SNP rs12908161 showed a posterior colocalisation probability of 1.00 with an i-eQTL targeting the unannotated expressed region DER36302, suggesting it had a strong association with schizophrenia-related expression.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: The GWAS lead SNP rs950169 displayed colocalisation with the i-eQTL targeting the region DER36302, reaffirming its link to the expression relevant to schizophrenia.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: The SNP rs3043909 was linked to the forced expression of ZNF143, suggesting its involvement in regulating cancer cell growth. This finding indicated that ZNF143 acts as a significant transcription factor that may inhibit cancer proliferation.
title: Putative Looping Factor ZNF143/ZFP143 is an Essential Transcriptional Regulator with No Looping Function

finding: For SNP rs1065080 in the SMAD3 gene, it was found to influence response to fluticasone and roflumilast. High responders to the treatment predominantly exhibited the homozygous alternative genotype (GG), contrasting with the poor response group where only 5 out of 13 patients displayed this genotype.
title: Application of Pharmacogenomics and Bioinformatics to Exemplify the Utility of Human ex vivo Organoculture Models in the Field of Precision Medicine

finding: Found to be an outlier for both total and ER-positive breast cancer, indicating its potential relevance in breast cancer risk.
title: Coffee consumption and risk of breast cancer: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: The A allele of the regulatory SNP rs1979905 was associated with higher CHRNA5 expression (t=27.87, p=5.94*10^-124). Furthermore, this variant predicted significantly reduced cortical beta-amyloid load, demonstrating a protective role in Alzheimer's Disease neuropathology.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to protection against amyloid pathology in human aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The missense SNP rs16969968 A allele was linked with impaired function/trafficking of nicotinic alpha-5 containing receptors. Homozygotes for this allele exhibited significantly lower proportions of chandelier cells with increasing beta-amyloid load (interaction term t=-2.86, p=0.004), indicating increased vulnerability of these neurons to amyloid pathology.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to protection against amyloid pathology in human aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The known variant rs113298164 was linked to HDL-C levels and shown to influence the association of the rs112147665 variant, demonstrating its important role in lipid metabolism.
title: Whole genome sequence analysis of blood lipid levels in >66,000 individuals

finding: The SNP rs1080066 on chromosome 15 was identified as the most significant lead SNP associated with regional brain morphology, with a p-value of 1.2 x 10^-305. It exhibited widespread effects on regional surface area and cortical thickness, showing positive effects with the minor allele.
title: Making the MOSTest of imaging genetics

finding: The SNP rs4702, located in the 3' region of the gene FURIN, was edited effectively in human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs). Bulk analysis revealed successful gene editing efficiencies ranging from 21.7% to 52.2% across various hiPSC lines, indicating its contribution to genetic modifications related to schizophrenia risk.
title: Publicly available hiPSC lines with extreme polygenic risk scores for modeling schizophrenia

finding: The original finding related to rs1426654 was that it is a large effect variant in the SCL24A5 gene, which had significant implications for skin pigmentation traits within the context of multi-ancestry studies.
title: Interpreting SNP heritability in admixed populations

finding: At the SLC24A5 locus (rs1426654), selection occurred even earlier, with the selected allele increasing in frequency and nearing fixation around 3,500 years ago, indicating early adaptation related to skin pigmentation.
title: The Selection Landscape and Genetic Legacy of Ancient Eurasians

finding: This SNP was identified as a causal variant in the SLC24A5 gene, known for its association with skin pigmentation diversity in European populations. It was revealed as being under positive selection.
title: Ohana: detecting selection in multiple populations by modelling ancestral admixture components

finding: The SNP rs55728265 was associated with Crohn's disease (CD) and type 1 diabetes (T1D). It lies within the 5' UTR of the RASGRP1 gene, which is crucial for T cell signaling and differentiation. The risk allele for rs55728265 was shown to increase reporter expression, highlighting its regulatory potential in T cell responses.
title: Prioritization of autoimmune disease-associated genetic variants that perturb regulatory element activity in T cells

finding: The SNP rs11071014 was associated with the regulation of tumor suppressor p53 activity, implicating it in the modulation of the p53 and Integrated Stress Response (ISR) pathways. Findings demonstrated that this SNP was part of the broader gene regulatory network influencing metabolic and pro-apoptotic genes, which are critical for anti-cancer strategies. This indicated its potential role in cancer therapies targeting p53 and ISR.
title: Shared gene regulatory strategies for the p53 and ATF4-dependent transcriptional networks

finding: The SNP rs8030221 was found to be positively associated with the variability in leaf reflectance related to environmental factors such as temperature and relative humidity. The findings indicated that alterations in these environmental variables influenced the biochemical traits predicted from leaf reflectance measurements, specifically an increase in carotene and a decrease in Nitrogen content.
title: Integration of leaf spectral reflectance variability facilitates identification of plant leaves at different taxonomic levels

finding: This SNP within the SMAD3 locus was categorized as a significant caQTL in SMCs, reinforcing its potential role in CAD mechanisms.
title: Cell-specific chromatin landscape of human coronary artery resolves regulatory mechanisms of disease risk

finding: SNP rs7165633 demonstrated a female-specific association with Mobiluncus mulieris, which is involved in vaginal infections.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs597414 was associated with type 2 diabetes as indicated by its genotypic p-value of 1.781 x 10^-7. This finding was notable because block HSIC Lasso selected it despite the p-value not being Bonferroni significant, showcasing its ability to improve classification accuracy.
title: Block HSIC Lasso: model-free biomarker detection for ultra-high dimensional data

finding: In the glomerular tissue, the genotype A/A at SNP rs8023408 was associated with higher SV2B expression, showing the significance of endothelial cell type-specific eQTL effects.
title: Mapping the genetic architecture of human traits to cell types in the kidney identifies mechanisms of disease and potential treatments

finding: OCA2 rs1800414 T/C was associated with skin color and tanning ability and showed positive selection with an estimated frequency increase that started around 25,000 years ago. This SNP's derived allele is prevalent in modern East Asians, supporting its evolutionary significance.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: SNP rs2073711 (A/G) located in the CILP gene was noted as another TIM. Its temporal variation indicated a trend of increasing frequency for the associated risk allele, likely influenced by lifestyle changes in ancient populations.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: SNP rs1426654 was identified as the lowest-cost characteristic SNP for the third split in the tangles tree, which differentiated between European and South Asian populations. This SNP is associated with iris color and skin pigmentation in South Asians.
title: Inferring Ancestry with the Hierarchical Soft Clustering Approach tangleGen

finding: The rs4702 G allele was associated with downregulation of FURIN expression through the action of miR-338-3p. This finding related to decreased BDNF production, implicating the importance of the FURIN gene in neuronal development and its potential connection to Schizophrenia.
title: The kpc-1 (furin) 3’UTR promotes dendritic transport and local translation of mRNAs to regulate dendrite branching and self-avoidance of a nociceptive neuron

finding: The CYP19A1 rs3751592 variant was associated with susceptibility to Alzheimer disease in the Chinese Han population, indicating its relevance in neurodegenerative disorders.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: SNP rs261290, near ALDH1A2, was reported to be associated with HDL (lead trait) as well as TC and TG according to GLGC data.
title: MetaPhat: Detecting and decomposing multivariate associations from univariate genome-wide association statistics

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was associated with human pigmentation, where it modulated pigmentation by attenuating the chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the promoter of the OCA2 gene. This finding was well-replicated and related to eye and hair color phenotypes.
title: GenNet framework: interpretable neural networks for phenotype prediction

finding: This SNP correlated with IDH2 and was implicated in a significant association with AMD, suggesting its potential relevance in geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs3825991 was associated with the PARP12 gene in the context of AMD, further linking it to geographic atrophy pathways.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: The allele rs17293632 (C > T) was shown to serve as a Ref-ASB for 25 different transcription factors. Its association with Crohn's disease indicated a role in affecting chromatin accessibility in the adjacent region, and it was located in the intron of SMAD3, overlapping an eQTL targeting SMAD3, AAGAB, and PIAS1 genes.
title: Landscape of allele-specific transcription factor binding in the human genome

finding: This variant was associated with increased transcriptional activity of Secretogranin 3 (SCG3) and the minor allele containing haplotype was found to be protective against high obesity with an odds ratio of 9.23 and a highly significant p-value of 7 x 10^-6. This discovery is striking as it had not been previously observed in European ancestry cohorts.
title: A survey of proteomic variation across two ethnic groups in Nigeria and its relationship to obesity risk

finding: Similar to rs16964465, this variant also affected transcriptional activity of SCG3 and was found to be protective for high-obesity (odds ratio of 9.23; p=7 x 10^-6). Both variants were absent in European-ancestry individuals but common in African populations, underscoring their relevance.
title: A survey of proteomic variation across two ethnic groups in Nigeria and its relationship to obesity risk

finding: The SNP rs16969968 was analyzed in relation to FEV1, a known risk locus for COPD and cigarette smoking. The study employed several regression models to assess the effect of this SNP on FEV1, adjusting for age, height, sex, and principal components. It was found that including regional principal components improved the evaluation of the association, leading to better insights into the genetic factors influencing FEV1.
title: locStra: Fast analysis of regional/global stratification in whole genome sequencing (WGS) studies

finding: This SNP was linked to coronary artery disease (beta=-0.073, p=5.97×10^-13), suggesting its importance in cardiovascular health.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: Associated with apolipoprotein A levels, this SNP's significance highlights its role in lipid metabolism.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in East Asians, contributing to respiratory phenotype findings.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: Found to show strong allele-specific methylation (ASM) in multiple myeloma cells with hypermethylation of the REF allele, corroborating its role as a potential regulatory SNP.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The SNP rs11633209 was associated with the gene LPAR6, where it presented a significant maternal expression pattern in regulating gene expression, with an adjusted p-value of 1.96×10^-66. This indicated its role as a candidate cis-eQTL with imprinting effects.
title: A statistical method for joint estimation of cis-eQTLs and parent-of-orign effects using an orthogonal framework with RNA-seq data

finding: The SNP rs4965238 was associated with the IGF1R gene and presented both a dominance effect and imprinting effect, with an adjusted p-value of 1.37×10^-67. This finding was significant in the context of understanding eQTL mapping, particularly concerning roles in cancer.
title: A statistical method for joint estimation of cis-eQTLs and parent-of-orign effects using an orthogonal framework with RNA-seq data

finding: The rs12913832 SNP was identified as modulating human pigmentation. It did this by attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding provided important information regarding the genetic basis of pigmentation traits, which are influenced by the interaction of different genetic elements.
title: Loss of MC1R signaling implicates TBX3 in pheomelanogenesis and melanoma predisposition

finding: The SNP rs2278458, located at chr15:22,999,857 in the CYFIP1 gene, had associations with Triglyceride levels and response to diuretics in individuals of European and African ancestry.
title: Continental-scale genomic analysis suggests shared post-admixture adaptation in Americas

finding: The lead variant rs35028925 has been associated with lung cancer risk. It is noteworthy that variants in the neighboring coding gene STRC were also highlighted in relation to breast cancer susceptibility, suggesting a potential link between these cancers.
title: Pleiotropy-guided transcriptome imputation from normal and tumor tissues identifies new candidate susceptibility genes for breast and ovarian cancer

finding: At the 15q14 locus, variant rs684374 was found in a chromatin site with increased activity specifically in glucocorticoid-treated islets. It had significant allelic effects on chromatin accessibility and disrupted a sequence motif for the glucocorticoid receptor, indicating its involvement in glucocorticoid signaling.
title: Glucocorticoid signaling in pancreatic islets modulates gene regulatory programs and genetic risk of type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs3784789 was linked to changes in DNA methylation at the cg26843110 locus, which in turn associated with shorter gestational age at birth and affected the expression of the CSK gene. This relationship underscores the genetic influence on birth weight and overall fetal development in the context of maternal smoking.
title: Placental DNA methylation signatures of maternal smoking during pregnancy and potential impacts on fetal growth

finding: The SNP rs755472529 was associated with the ancestral alleles of the KNL1 gene, which were present among Neandertals but not in the genomes of present-day humans. This finding exemplified that gene flow from Neandertals contributed derived variants of KNL1 to modern humans. Moreover, there was only one instance in the whole-genome sequences studied where the ancestral allele was detected, possibly indicating a back mutation. The absence of ancestral alleles in the exome sequences suggested they may have been disadvantageous and effectively eliminated after the admixture events with Neandertals and Denisovans.
title: The evolutionary history of human spindle genes includes back-and-forth gene flow with Neandertals

finding: The SNP rs16969968 was identified as a significant variant in the context of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor alpha5 polymorphism, playing a crucial role in the association with various diseases, including those affecting lung homeostasis and respiratory diseases.
title: Nicotinic receptors atlas in the adult human lung

finding: The finding related to rs1129038 indicated that this variant inhibited gene regulation and was associated with the blue eye color phenotype. It was identified as the best-ranked variant in the European (EUR) group, demonstrating its significance in the study of positive selection.
title: Modeling recent positive selection in Americans of European ancestry

finding: The variant rs2470890, located in CYP1A2, was found at elevated frequencies in all non-African populations, suggesting its potential influence on metabolism and adaptation.
title: Archaic introgression and variation in pharmacogenes and implications for local adaptation

finding: The study authored by Vitti and Parsons in 2019 reported that the SNP rs11070946 was associated with the radiobiological effects of proton beam therapy, specifically impacting DNA damage and the efficiency of DNA repair in cancer cells. This finding was significant as it highlighted the role of specific genetic variants in influencing the cellular response to ionizing radiation, which is crucial for the effectiveness of cancer treatments.
title: The DNA damage response relies on the characteristics of ionizing particles in myogenic cells

finding: The rs11072494 variant was part of a set of four variants linked to multiple trans-eGenes associated with cleft palate, cleft lip, and hemifacial microsomia. These downstream genes were enriched in biological processes associated with the JNK cascade and MAPK cascade, which are known to have implications in congenital craniofacial abnormalities.
