title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: Similar to rs11072494, rs2289187 was part of the same set of four variants linked to six downstream trans-eGenes related to cleft palate and other craniofacial abnormalities, contributing to the overall enrichment in JNK and MAPK biological processes.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: This SNP was included in the group of four variants associated with the same set of trans-eGenes involved in cleft abnormalities, emphasizing its relevance to disorders like cleft lip and palate through association with the JNK and MAPK signaling pathways.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: The rs6495117 variant was also among the four variants linked to six downstream trans-eGenes for cleft lip and palate, further corroborating associations with critical developmental signaling pathways involved in congenital craniofacial anomalies.
title: Systematic assessment of regulatory effects of human disease variants in pluripotent cells

finding: This SNP was identified as genome-wide significant in the variant-based GWAS with a p-value of 1.9e-08, although it was not found in the largest BMI meta-GWAS.
title: Quantitative Genetic Scoring, or how to put a number on an arbitrary genetic region

finding: In the joint analysis of brain morphology using MOSTest, rs1080066 on chromosome 15 demonstrated significant association with regional surface area and cortical thickness measures, achieving a p-value of 1.2×10^-305. The Z-values indicated positive effects for carrying the minor allele on brain morphology features.
title: Making the MOSTest of imaging genetics

finding: This SNP was identified in a variant-based GWAS analysis for BMI, showing a genome-wide significant variant (p=1.9e-08). However, it was not found in the largest BMI meta-GWAS, indicating limited impact in broader studies.
title: Quantitative Genetic Scoring, or how to put a number on an arbitrary genetic region

finding: The SNP rs7163757 was linked to the gene C2CD4B in alpha cells, with a posterior probability of association (PPAg) of 0.095. This finding corroborated previous studies that associated rs7163757 with C2CD4B expression, further validated by functional studies.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs17293632 was associated with Crohn’s disease and served as a Ref-ASB for 25 different transcription factors. It was located in the SMAD3 intron, functioning as an eQTL for the SMAD3, AAGAB, and PIAS1 genes.
title: Landscape of allele-specific transcription factor binding in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs11071037 was identified as being associated with the expression of the AP-1 transcription factor in female immune cells. This finding related to the inflammatory core observed in female immune responses during the inflammatory-predominant forms of multiple sclerosis, where AP-1 appeared to play a regulatory role.
title: Single cell landscape of sex differences in the progression of multiple sclerosisg

finding: The SNP rs16969968 was examined in the context of its association with FEV1, identified as a well-established risk locus for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and cigarette smoking. The analysis utilized three regression models to assess the SNP's effects on FEV1, including adjustments for demographic factors and principal components. The finding noted the SNP's significant allele frequency of 0.597, confirming its role in the studied population size of 5,765 subjects.
title: locStra: Fast analysis of regional/global stratification in whole genome sequencing (WGS) studies

finding: This SNP was identified near SMAD3 and associated with multiple autoimmune diseases including ankylosing spondylitis (AS), chronic rhinosinusitis (CR), multiple sclerosis (MS), psoriasis (PS), rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and ulcerative colitis (UC), significantly altering almost all three transcription factors' binding propensities.
title: The AP-1 factors FOSL1 and FOSL2 co-regulate human Th17 responses

finding: The missense variant rs139709573 (NP_510883.2:p.P155L) in TM2D3 was reported to significantly increase the risk of developing Late-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (LOAD), with an odds ratio of 7.45 and a p-value of 6.6×10^-9 in an exome-wide association analysis. The variant was also associated with an earlier age-at-onset of the disease, indicating a potential difference of up to 10 years, and had a hazard ratio of 5.3 after adjusting for the APOE ε4 allele. Experimental assays demonstrated that this variant had deleterious effects on the function of TM2D3, with implications for both Alzheimer's disease pathology and the evolutionarily conserved role of TM2D3 related to Notch signaling.
title: Alzheimer’s disease-associated TM2D genes regulate Notch signaling and neuronal function in Drosophila

finding: The SNP rs11070971 was associated with immune response variations which impacted the efficacy of tebentafusp, a bispecific T cell engaging therapy, in patients with metastatic uveal melanoma. The altered immune responses led to different survival outcomes as evidenced in a randomized phase 3 clinical trial.
title: Tuning the potency and therapeutic window of ImmTAC molecules by affinity modulation

finding: The SNP rs3204689 was associated with severe hand osteoarthritis (OA). This was demonstrated by a genome-wide association study (GWAS), with an odds ratio of 1.46 for severe hand OA, correlating with higher prevalence among individuals possessing the risk allele. Further confirmation was made in the UK Biobank cohort, where the risk allele showed a significant association with hand OA (OR 1.15, 95% CI 1.08-1.23, p = 2.5×10^-5). Additionally, expression levels of the ALDH1A2 gene were significantly lower in articular cartilage from individuals who were homozygous or heterozygous for this risk variant, indicating its potential role in the pathology of OA.
title: Variants in ALDH1A2 reveal an anti-inflammatory role for retinoic acid and a new class of disease-modifying drugs in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs4238326 also showed a significant association with severe hand OA, with an odds ratio reported at 1.44, further confirming its link to the condition. In the replication analysis using the UK Biobank cohort, this SNP was found to have an odds ratio of 1.16 (95% CI 1.09-1.25, p = 1.1×10^-5). Similar to rs3204689, the ALDH1A2 mRNA levels were reduced in the cartilage of individuals homozygous or heterozygous for risk alleles, supporting the hypothesis that these polymorphisms influence the development of hand OA.
title: Variants in ALDH1A2 reveal an anti-inflammatory role for retinoic acid and a new class of disease-modifying drugs in osteoarthritis

finding: This SNP was classified as causal for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). NLDNN was notably effective in detecting this SNP against the performance of other models.
title: Cross-species prediction of transcription factor binding by adversarial training of a novel nucleotide-level deep neural network

finding: The rs12437854 SNP was associated with DKD based on previous findings (P = 2.97×10^-5), contributing to understanding of genetic risks in diabetic nephropathy.
title: Genome-wide association study of diabetic kidney disease highlights biology involved in renal basement membrane collagen

finding: The SNP rs1879454 was predicted to regulate the expression of TLNRD1, a newly identified gene related to CAD. This variant was located in a chromatin accessible region, disrupting a GATA motif, which was shown to be significant for gene expression regulation in endothelial cells. The A allele was associated with a 2-fold decrease in allele-specific GATA2 ChIP-seq signal and a 2.4-fold decrease in ATAC-seq signal, suggesting a protective role against CAD.
title: Mapping the convergence of genes for coronary artery disease onto endothelial cell programs

finding: The study reported that rs146353869 in the FAN1 gene was identified as a previously-identified GWAS modifier for Huntington disease (HD). This variant, despite its low minor allele frequency of 2%, was associated with a significant average age of onset (AOO) alteration of 6.1 years, indicating its impact on the progression of HD.
title: Length of uninterrupted CAG repeats, independent of polyglutamine size, results in increased somatic instability and hastened age of onset in Huntington disease

finding: SNP rs5742915 was recognized as a missense variant in the PML gene. It was fine-mapped with a PIP of 1.000 for pulse rate, 0.987 for total protein level, and 0.858 for FEV1-FVC ratio. This highlighted its potential as a causal variant and indicated possible pleiotropic effects impacting multiple biomarkers.
title: SparsePro: an efficient genome-wide fine-mapping method integrating summary statistics and functional annotations

finding: The p.R153H variant (rs12595158) was nominally associated with a reduced risk for PD in the New York cohort, but it did not remain statistically significant after correction for multiple comparisons.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The p.I398I variant (rs9635356) showed a nominal association with reduced risk for PD in the New York cohort, similar to other variants, but did not reach significance after multiple comparison adjustments.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The p.I1132V variant (rs3784635) remained statistically significant after correction for multiple comparisons, indicating it was associated with reduced risk for PD.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The p.Q2376Q variant (rs17238189) was associated with reduced risk for PD in the New York cohort but did not remain significant after correction for multiple comparisons.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: This variant was associated with disease in FinnGen despite the lead PCSK6 variant not being associated, indicating its importance in fine-mapping.
title: An expanded analysis framework for multivariate GWAS connects inflammatory biomarkers to functional variants and disease

finding: The SNP rs11070970 was found to have a significant association with the expression of miR-221 and miR-222, which were correlated with various clinical outcomes in cancer patients. This finding relates to the prognostic role of these microRNAs in cancer, indicating that genetic variations at this locus could influence tumor behavior and patient survival.
title: Cancer metabolic subtypes and their association with molecular and clinical features

finding: The common variant rs28890483 located at the 5' side of the DRACC1 gene was linked to increased risk for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. This finding was significant in understanding the genetic basis of neuropsychiatric disorders as DRACC1 was implicated in depression susceptibility, highlighting its role in neuronal activity.
title: DRACC1, a major postsynaptic protein, regulates the condensation of postsynaptic proteins via liquid-liquid phase separation

finding: Similar to rs28890483, the variant rs10519005 was associated with the expression levels of DRACC1, which were suggested to contribute to the risk of alcohol dependence and other neuropsychiatric disorders. The identification of this SNP reinforced the importance of DRACC1 in the context of mental health, particularly regarding its influence on neuronal functioning.
title: DRACC1, a major postsynaptic protein, regulates the condensation of postsynaptic proteins via liquid-liquid phase separation

finding: The SNP rs16969968, a nicotinic receptor alpha5 coding polymorphism, was identified as a major target in disease contexts. The study characterized its functional implications, particularly in relation to nicotine addiction and lung disease pathways, emphasizing its relevance in understanding the pathology associated with lung homeostasis and respiratory diseases.
title: Nicotinic receptors atlas in the adult human lung

finding: This SNP mapped to the DAO gene, which has been associated with general cognitive ability and exploratory eye movement dysfunction in schizophrenia, with significant p-values from previous studies.
title: Comparing the XGBoost machine learning algorithm to polygenic scoring for the prediction of intelligence based on genotype data

finding: In a study focusing on pancreatic differentiation, it was demonstrated that the T2D-associated SNP rs528350911, located within the ONECUT1e-664kb enhancer, disrupted a GATA motif critical for transcription factor binding. This variant was shown to significantly reduce the binding of key pancreatic transcription factors GATA4, GATA6, and FOXA2 to the enhancer, which in turn affected ONECUT1 gene expression during differentiation, linking the variant to potential metabolic disease susceptibility.
title: CRISPR Screening Uncovers a Long-Range Enhancer for ONECUT1 in Pancreatic Differentiation and Links a Diabetes Risk Variant

finding: This SNP was identified in strong linkage disequilibrium with the CAD sentinel variant rs2521501. It maps within the <italic>FES</italic> promoter and was shown to be an eQTL for <italic>FES</italic>. In CRISPR experiments, it significantly up-regulated both <italic>FES</italic> (log2FC=3.75) and <italic>FURIN</italic> (log2FC=0.78), indicating its regulatory role.
title: CRISPR perturbations at many coronary artery disease loci impair vascular endothelial cell functions

finding: The neuromedin B gene polymorphism rs3809508 influenced the risk of obesity, which is a condition relevant to cardiovascular diseases including heart failure.
title: Identification of biomarkers, pathways and potential therapeutic targets for heart failure using bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs16969968 was reported as a well-established functional missense SNP in the CHRNA5 gene, demonstrating a strong association with ND from prior research. Its association with smoking behaviors, particularly ND, was confirmed in this study.
title: Expanding the Genetic Architecture of Nicotine Dependence and its Shared Genetics with Multiple Traits: Findings from the Nicotine Dependence GenOmics (iNDiGO) Consortium

finding: The SNP rs12595158 was part of a haplotype associated with a reduced risk for Parkinson Disease in the New York cohort, showing a nominal association that suggested potential protective effects.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The SNP rs9635356 contributed to the haplotype associated with reduced risk for Parkinson Disease, being nominally significant in the New York cohort without showing ethnicity impact, indicating a consistent directionality across different groups.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The SNP rs3784635 was also included in the protective haplotype showing a reduced risk for Parkinson Disease in the New York cohort, further confirming the association identified with the other linked SNPs.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The SNP rs17238189 was among the four variants of a haplotype that exhibited a nominal protective association against Parkinson Disease primarily in the New York cohort.
title: Analysis of common and rare VPS13C variants in late onset Parkinson disease

finding: The SNP rs4238361 was suggested as a potential risk modifying variant for Parkinson's Disease (PD). It was associated with the gene VPS13C, which harbored both rare and common variants of interest related to PD. This finding indicated its relevance in understanding genetic aspects of PD biology.
title: Multi-Modality Machine Learning Predicting Parkinson’s Disease

finding: For the OCA2 locus, SIA detected a moderate selection signal with a probability of 0.75 and a selection coefficient approximately equal to 0.0056, indicating its involvement in pigmentation.
title: SIA: Selection Inference Using the Ancestral Recombination Graph

finding: The SNP rs11070948 was identified as having a connection to stearoyl-CoA desaturase 1 (SCD1) functioning, where inhibition of SCD1 was shown to have therapeutic implications in cancers, particularly in acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). This finding was significant because it indicated that this genetic variation may relate to therapeutic vulnerabilities in AML, appreciating the dependency on fatty acid desaturation.
title: SCD inhibition preferentially eradicates AML displaying high de novo fatty acid desaturation and synergizes with chemotherapy

finding: The SNP rs11635336 was associated with the regulation of the L1 family gene set, showing significant upregulation (NES = 3.74, FDR = 6.43E-41) in response to genotype changes involving IL16 and STARD5.
title: A Computational Approach for the Identification of Novel L1 Transcriptional Regulators

finding: This SNP was associated with predicting tree-related microhabitats by utilizing multisensor close-range remote sensing structural parameters, contributing to the understanding of habitat selection in forests.
title: Spatial distribution of Tree-related Microhabitats in a primeval mountain forest: from natural patterns to landscape planning and forest management recommendations

finding: The SNP rs2470102 was originally associated with skin colour variation in Indian populations, linked to potential effects on the miR-1180-3p target site in the MYEF2 gene. There was a significant association found between the frequency of the target allele and absolute latitude, indicating potential selective pressures related to UV exposure.
title: Pervasive selection against microRNA target sites in human populations

finding: The SNP rs17293632 (C>T) was predicted to strongly affect the binding of the transcription factor FOS to an overlapping <k>k</k>-mer, indicated by the highest absolute value of the ΔMOCCS2score (226.1), which was 40% of the ΔMOCCS2scores of top ChIP-seq samples. This finding related to Crohn's disease as rs17293632 was reported as a CD-associated variant.
title: MOCCS profile analysis clarifies the cell type dependency of transcription factor-binding sequences and cis-regulatory SNPs in humans

finding: SNP rs7497304 was found in a pair with SNP rs2677738, showing a correlation of 0.49, and was included in the analysis of SNPs associated with hypertension phenotypes.
title: Iterative Hard Thresholding in GWAS: Generalized Linear Models, Prior Weights, and Double Sparsity

finding: SNP rs2677738, paired with SNP rs7497304 with a correlation of 0.49, was also linked to hypertension phenotypes in the study.
title: Iterative Hard Thresholding in GWAS: Generalized Linear Models, Prior Weights, and Double Sparsity

finding: The SNP rs12913832 represented a crucial mutation responsible for producing blue eyes through a single letter alteration on the HERC2 gene. This change significantly reduced melanin production by fivefold, leading to lighter eye colors such as blue, while the ancestral allele promoted increased melanin, resulting in dark-brown eyes. This discovery contributed to a deeper understanding of eye color inheritance, particularly in the context of sex-linked traits.
title: Sex tweaks eye color

finding: The R264C variant (rs700519) of CYP19A1 was identified as a common polymorphic variant, especially prevalent in Asian and African populations, with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.17 in East Asian, 0.24 in South East Asian, and 0.18 in African populations. It exhibited only 15% of aromatase activity with the WT-POR as a redox partner, indicating a significant reduction in enzyme function.
title: Differential effects of variations in human P450 oxidoreductase on the aromatase activity of CYP19A1 polymorphisms R264C and R264H

finding: The R264H variant (rs2304462) of CYP19A1 was characterized as a rare polymorphism, showing a MAF of 0.00003 in ExAC Aggregated Populations. This variant displayed 87% of aromatase activity when paired with WT-POR, and notably, more than three-fold higher activity compared to WT-CYP19A1 using POR-Y607C as a redox partner, suggesting a beneficial effect on activity.
title: Differential effects of variations in human P450 oxidoreductase on the aromatase activity of CYP19A1 polymorphisms R264C and R264H

finding: The SNP rs2250072, located in the SLC24A5 gene, showed a strong link with skin pigmentation variations and was under positive selection in European populations. It was associated with a derived allele correlating with lighter skin phenotypes.
title: A fast linkage disequilibrium-based statistical test for Genome-Wide Epistatic Selection Scans in structured populations

finding: For SNP rs13737, a negative effect on the expression of MAN2C1 was observed across all tissues, with a NES of -0.68 (P <= 6.49·10^-17). This finding suggested a potential role in inhibiting the PI3K-AKT signaling pathway involved in T2D development.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The SNP rs4932265 was found to increase the expression of AP3S2 across twelve tissues, having a mean NES of 0.65 (P <= 3.02·10^-13). This association highlighted its connection to vesicle budding from the Golgi membrane, implicating it in T2D susceptibility.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The SNP rs11071008 was reported in studies examining cancer cell response to mechanical stress, highlighting its significance in the modified mechanobiological profiles of tumors. The research by Bregenzer et al. (2019) underscored the importance of this SNP in understanding cellular dynamics under strain, which could be crucial for development and invasion of cancer cells.
title: A flexible micro-piston device for mechanical cell stimulation and compression in microfluidic settings

finding: The study related to the SNP rs8042919 involved a trial where the interaction between this TRPM7 genotype and magnesium supplementation was investigated in the context of colorectal carcinogenesis biomarkers. Participants with a personal history of colorectal polyps and the specific TRPM7 genotype were assessed for biomarkers after receiving either magnesium or placebo. This finding suggested a potential impact of the TRPM7 genotype on the efficacy of magnesium supplementation regarding colorectal health.
title: On the robustness of inference of association with the gut microbiota in stool, swab and mucosal tissue samples

finding: The Ap3s2 gene rs2028299 was linked to type 2 diabetes in the northern Chinese Han population, further supporting the genetic basis of T2DM susceptibility.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: SIA detected a moderate signal of selection at rs12913832 within the OCA2 gene, with a sweep probability of 0.75 and a selection coefficient around 0.0056, also related to pigmentation.
title: SIA: Selection Inference Using the Ancestral Recombination Graph

finding: The SNP rs1426654 in the SLC24A5 gene exhibited the largest selection difference between Europeans and East Asians, confirming strong directional selection in Europeans for light pigmentation.
title: Dissecting dynamics and differences of selective pressures in the evolution of human pigmentation

finding: The SNP rs1800414 in the OCA2 gene had a notable selection difference between East Asians and other populations, showing evidence of directional selection contributing to light pigmentation.
title: Dissecting dynamics and differences of selective pressures in the evolution of human pigmentation

finding: The SNP rs1800401, located in the OCA2 gene, was associated with dark pigmentation and differed significantly between West Africans and Eurasians, indicating potential selection signals in pigmentation.
title: Dissecting dynamics and differences of selective pressures in the evolution of human pigmentation

finding: The variant rs1051168 was identified as a progenitor eSNP regulating NMB gene expression. It was colocalized with the schizophrenia GWAS index SNP rs12908161, where the risk allele (G) was associated with decreased NMB expression.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: Variant rs12908161 was noted as an index SNP for schizophrenia and found in the same regulatory context as rs1051168, suggesting its role in risk for schizophrenia through the modulation of NMB expression.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: The SNP rs3204689 was associated with severe hand osteoarthritis (OA) in a genome-wide association study, demonstrating an odds ratio of 1.46. This finding was confirmed in the UK Biobank cohort, where it showed an odds ratio of 1.15 (95% CI 1.08-1.23, p = 2.5×10^-5). Genotyping indicated a high prevalence of the risk-conferring C allele among studied individuals.
title: Variants in ALDH1A2 reveal an anti-inflammatory role for retinoic acid and a new class of disease-modifying drugs in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs4238326 was also linked to severe hand osteoarthritis, with an odds ratio of 1.44 noted in the original study. In the UK Biobank, it was found to have an odds ratio of 1.16 (95% CI 1.09-1.25, p = 1.1×10^-5), corroborating its association with hand OA. This SNP was similarly prevalent in the patient population analyzed.
title: Variants in ALDH1A2 reveal an anti-inflammatory role for retinoic acid and a new class of disease-modifying drugs in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was found to influence human pigmentation by modulating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding highlighted the SNP's role in pigmentation and melanoma risk in humans, with its allelic variations being relevant for these traits.
title: Transcriptional co-activator regulates melanocyte differentiation and oncogenesis by integrating cAMP and MAPK/ERK pathways

finding: The missense SNP rs16969968 was associated with lower expression of the CHRNA5 gene. Specifically, homozygous A allele carriers demonstrated a reduced proportion of chandelier cells in the prefrontal cortex when exposed to high β-amyloid levels, indicating that this SNP may compromise the neuroprotective role of the nicotinic α5 subunit against amyloid pathology.
title: Common genetic variants in CHRNA5 alter β-amyloid neuropathology and highlight chandelier cells in human aging and Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The regulatory SNP rs1979905 was found to be positively associated with higher expression levels of the CHRNA5 gene. Furthermore, carriers of the A allele showed a significant negative correlation with β-amyloid load, suggesting that this SNP might contribute to reduced amyloid accumulation in the brain, highlighting its potential neuroprotective role in Alzheimer's Disease.
title: Common genetic variants in CHRNA5 alter β-amyloid neuropathology and highlight chandelier cells in human aging and Alzheimer’s disease

finding: This variant was identified in three significant pairwise interactions involved in skin color but was originally reported in the context of hair color interactions, reaffirming its role in the genetic configuration correlating with skin phenotype.
title: Dispensing with unnecessary assumptions in population genetics analysis

finding: The study identified rs1655558 as a potential causal variant influencing the expression of the long non-coding RNA OIP5-AS1 in multiple brain cell types, including excitatory neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes. This association was crucial for understanding how OIP5-AS1 interacts with HDAC proteins, particularly HDAC11, in relation to Alzheimer's disease traits such as amyloid plaques and tau tangles.
title: Spatial Expression of Long Non-Coding RNAs in Human Brains of Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs2073711 (A/G) SNP located in the CILP gene was associated with cartilage scaffolding and demonstrated a temporal variation trend that indicated an increase in the frequency of the risk allele due to lifestyle and dietary changes. This SNP was categorized as a TIM.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: The rs7183877 (C/A) SNP, part of a haplotype in the HERC gene associated with blue eye color, was noted for its prevalence in Caucasians and showed temporal variation in allele frequency, which marked it as a TIM. This indicated evolutionary pressures affecting pigmentation traits.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: The rs8028689 (T/C) SNP within the same haplotype as rs7183877, also associated with eye color, demonstrated changes in frequency that aligned with shifts in human pigmentation traits over time, solidifying its status as a TIM.
title: A genomic dating tool for ancient genomes resolves the origins of hundreds of Eurasian genomes

finding: Research on SNP rs12101693 confirmed that it could be utilized for detecting Grapevine Leafroll-Associated Virus in vineyard cultivars. This finding highlighted the potential of hyperspectral imaging to identify infections in grapevines, contributing significantly to sustainable viticulture.
title: Scalable early detection of grapevine virus infection with airborne imaging spectroscopy

finding: rs4779584 was replicated in the study with p=0.018, reinforcing its association as a risk factor for colorectal cancer.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: Replication of the association for rs11632715 was successfully achieved, with a significant p-value of 0.004, sustaining its candidacy as a colorectal cancer risk variant.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: This SNP was also shown to replicate its association with colorectal cancer risk (p=0.010), supporting findings from previous studies.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: Although not listed as initially studied before, rs10083612 within the SCG5 gene exhibited the most significant association (p=1.61e-5) and was thus highlighted in this analysis.
title: Genetic Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer in Multiethnic Indonesians

finding: The SNP rs3784609 was linked to the gene RORA, a lipid-sensing nuclear receptor that was broadly lowly expressed in cerebrovascular cell types including capillary and venule endothelial cells in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). This connection was established through various genetic evidence such as endothelial Hi-C chromatin loops and specific eQTLs. RORA was previously known to regulate inflammation and its low expression in AD may contribute to vascular dysregulation.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs442495 was linked to ADAM10, which is crucial for dendritic spine formation and overall AD pathology. It was identified through Hi-C and tissue-eQTL evidence. ADAM10 was differentially expressed across various cell types in AD and interacted with several receptors, implicating it in signaling pathways that affected endothelial gene expressions related to lipid storage and immune response.
title: Single-cell multi-region dissection of brain vasculature in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs2140734 was identified as being significantly associated with the expression of the gene MTMR10, exhibiting a Spearman's rank correlation of 0.24 and a P-value of 8.51 × 10⁻⁸. Additionally, this variant was noted to delay the age of onset of Huntington disease by 1.4 years. This finding was derived from a combination of TWAS analyses and corroborated with eQTL data, highlighting its role in the genetic modulation of Huntington disease.
title: Gene expression profiles complement the analysis of genomic modifiers of the clinical onset of Huntington disease

finding: The SNP rs78366152 was discovered as a cell type specific (CTS) cis-eQTL for the Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk gene AP3B2. This finding was significant in microglia, oligodendrocyte, and astrocyte cell types but not in excitatory neurons. Additionally, rs78366152 was noted to reside in a microglia-specific ATAC-seq peak that formed a chromatin loop with the AP3B2 promoter region, suggesting a microglia-specific regulatory effect on AP3B2 expression.
title: Cell-type specific inference from bulk RNA-sequencing data by integrating single cell reference profiles via EPIC-unmix

finding: The rs17293632 located in the SMAD3 region demonstrated the highest posterior probability in fine-mapping for Crohn’s disease. The T allele is associated with decreased expression of the enhancer ADDG15067442347.E across relevant cell types, and was linked to risks for Crohn's disease, asthma, and coronary artery disease.
title: Predicting cell-type-specific non-coding RNA transcription from genome sequence

finding: The lead variant rs35028925 in the gene STRC was previously associated with lung cancer risk, demonstrating the potential overlap between different cancer types.
title: Pleiotropy-guided transcriptome imputation from normal and tumor tissues identifies new candidate susceptibility genes for breast and ovarian cancer

finding: An association was documented between rs11547207 in CIB2 and cis-eQTLs with a significance of p=1.85 x 10^-27. This finding was identified through transcriptome and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) analysis on retinal tissues from human AMD patients, indicating a potential role of CIB2 in age-related macular degeneration pathology.
title: CIB2 regulates autophagy via Rheb-mTORC1 signaling axis

finding: rs1080066 showed the strongest association with precentral surface area and was implicated in synaptic functions, associated with fine-motor function in humans. Its role as a fetal cortex eQTL suggested developmental importance.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: This SNP was newly identified in the context of blood pressure-related traits and was found to be associated with DLL4, a gene involved in angiogenesis via Notch signaling, establishing a novel link with vascular biology.
title: Chromatin interaction maps of human arterioles reveal new mechanisms for the genetic regulation of blood pressure

finding: Previously associated with neuroticism, this SNP was also identified as a potentially pathogenic variant, underscoring its significance in the genetic study of neuroticism.
title: Gene-based association analysis identified 190 genes with polymorphisms affecting neuroticism

finding: At the C2CD4A/B locus, rs7163757 was linked to C2CD4B expression in alpha cells. Previous studies corroborated this association with C2CD4B expression, supporting the finding as a significant genetic predisposition for type 2 diabetes (T2D).
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was identified as the most significant variant associated with eye colour variation, functioning as an enhancer that regulates the expression of the downstream gene OCA2. The T-allele was shown to support chromatin loop formation with the OCA2 promoter, leading to increased transcription, while the C-allele inhibited this interaction, decreasing OCA2 expression. This SNP was particularly notable as several individuals with this genotype did not present with blue eyes, suggesting possible influence from additional variants in the HERC2/OCA2 locus.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: This SNP within the HERC2 gene was identified as an independent significant marker associated with eye colour, showcasing its importance in the genetic framework of pigmentation.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: The SNP <italic>rs16969968</italic> located on chromosome 15 was confirmed as a significant risk locus for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and associated with cigarette smoking behavior. It was included in multiple regression models analyzing its impact on FEV<sub>1</sub> while adjusting for age, height, gender, and principal components.
title: locStra: Fast analysis of regional/global stratification in whole genome sequencing (WGS) studies

finding: The variant rs28374715 was associated with an increased risk of ulcerative colitis, with a p-value of 2.43E-08 and an odds ratio (OR) of 1.08 (1.04-1.13) in European ancestry individuals, highlighting its significance in the context of ulcerative colitis risk.
title: RTF1 mediates epigenetic control of Th17 cell differentiation via H2B monoubiquitination

finding: The variant rs2777491 was associated with a decreased risk of ulcerative colitis, demonstrating a p-value of 8.32E-08 and an OR of 0.94 (0.91-0.96) in European ancestry individuals, underscoring a protective effect against ulcerative colitis.
title: RTF1 mediates epigenetic control of Th17 cell differentiation via H2B monoubiquitination

finding: The variant rs12440045 exhibited a robust association with neutrophil counts, indicating its role in immune response, particularly in the context of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) where neutrophil infiltration relates closely to disease severity.
title: RTF1 mediates epigenetic control of Th17 cell differentiation via H2B monoubiquitination

finding: The Val433Met variant was identified as the sentinel cis pQTL for ITGA11 (p=2.1×10-212, effect=-0.36 SD) and conferred risk of Dupuytren contracture (OR=1.27) and uterine fibroids (OR=1.12).
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: The SNP rs783540 was linked to the gene AP3B2, which had splicing and expression QTL associations. Despite having a high locus to gene score, its functional role was prioritized given its interaction with other schizophrenia-associated genes.
title: An atlas of protein-protein associations of human tissues prioritizes candidate disease genes

finding: The rs3825807 SNP, which results in a p.Ser214Pro coding variant, was identified as part of a risk haplotype associated with coronary artery disease (CAD). The risk variant increased prodomain processing and maturation, leading to enhanced degradation of cartilage oligomeric matrix protein (COMP) and increased vascular smooth muscle cell migration. Additionally, this Ser214 risk allele was linked to an unstable atherosclerotic plaque phenotype and a higher incidence of secondary cardiac events. Mouse knockout studies demonstrated that loss-of-function of Adamts7 significantly decreased neointimal formation following arterial wire injury, supporting the pathogenic role of the Ser214 variant in vascular smooth muscle cell dynamics.
title: TAILS identifies candidate substrates and biomarkers of ADAMTS7, a therapeutic protease target in coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs11071021 was linked to breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) dynamics in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). In particular, the finding highlighted that the presence of this SNP correlated with the efficiency of γδ T cells in recognizing and killing patient-derived BCSCs. This enabled the understanding of immune escape mechanisms whereby xenografted BCSCs lost key surface markers due to the influence of this genetic variant, impacting the efficacy of immunotherapy.
title: Breast cancer stem cell-derived tumors escape from γδ T cell immunosurveillance in vivo by modulating γδ T cell ligands

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was found to modulate human pigmentation by attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter. This finding effectively illustrated the functional impact of the SNP in relation to pigmentation traits.
title: GenNet framework: interpretable neural networks for phenotype prediction

finding: The variant rs56350203 located at chr15:70140778:G:C was found to act as a caQTL for a cRE upstream of the TLE3 gene. It showed increased accessibility in acinar cells (effect=0.70, FDR=9.7×10^-13) and decreased accessibility in alpha cells (effect=0.37, FDR=1.9×10^-12), indicating cell type-specific regulatory effects.
title: Single cell multiome profiling of pancreatic islets reveals physiological changes in cell type-specific regulation associated with diabetes risk

finding: This variant corresponds to rs56350203, demonstrating a clear example of lineage-specific effects on gene regulation tied to diabetes risk.
title: Single cell multiome profiling of pancreatic islets reveals physiological changes in cell type-specific regulation associated with diabetes risk

finding: The SNP rs269868 (C>T: Ser1067Leu) was positively selected in the Andean populations, with a C allele frequency of 0.53 in Andes compared to 0.01 in Amazon populations. This SNP is located in the A-loop region associated with DUOX2's interaction with its coactivator DUOXA2, and its mutation could impact the stability and maturation of DUOX2, affecting hydrogen peroxide production necessary for innate immunity.
title: The genetic structure and adaptation of Andean highlanders and Amazonian dwellers is influenced by the interplay between geography and culture

finding: The SNP rs57659670 (T>C: His678Arg) exhibited a similar pattern of positive selection in the Andean populations, with a C allele frequency of 0.53 in Andes and 0.01 in Amazon populations. This SNP also contributes to the evidence of adaptation under the environmental conditions of the Andean region, though the exact connection to thyroid function or innate immunity was not fully clarified in the study.
title: The genetic structure and adaptation of Andean highlanders and Amazonian dwellers is influenced by the interplay between geography and culture

finding: This rare variant in the gene DISP2 was negatively associated with age, demonstrating a significant association where carriers were on average 12 years younger than non-carriers. It was characterized as the top age-related variant based on its replication with directional consistency across multiple cohorts.
title: Exome-wide association studies in general and long-lived populations identify genetic variants related to human age

finding: The rs17293632 SNP in the SMAD3 region was noted for its strong association with Crohn's disease risk, asthma, and coronary artery disease. The T allele was predicted to decrease the expression of an enhancer, demonstrating significant implications for transcriptional activity across various cell types.
title: Predicting cell-type-specific non-coding RNA transcription from genome sequence

finding: The nonsynonymous SNP rs121918166 was associated with the phenotype 'Use of sun/uv protection' (UK Biobank Field ID: 2267). It had a minor allele frequency of 0.9% and a p-value of 5.2E-31. Higher usage of sun/UV protection was observed among subjects with a greater frequency of the minor allele T, linked to the gene OCA2, which plays a role in mammalian pigmentation and has been connected to human eye color and melanoma in previous studies.
title: Efficient mixed model approach for large-scale genome-wide association studies of ordinal categorical phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs117116488 was also linked to the phenotype 'Comparative height size at age 10' (UK Biobank Field ID: 1697). It had a minor allele frequency of 0.99% and a p-value of 1.4E-18, and it is connected to the gene ACAN.
title: Efficient mixed model approach for large-scale genome-wide association studies of ordinal categorical phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs4646626 was among the significant SNPs presented in the study, also characterized by a high CADD score, suggesting its potential deleterious impact on biological functions relevant to volumetric imaging derived phenotypes.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs6224 was associated with schizophrenia at genome-wide levels of significance. It exhibited an effect where the alleles linked to increased odds of left-handedness were also linked to an increased risk of schizophrenia.
title: RSGenome-wide association study identifies 49 common genetic variants associated with handedness

finding: The R264C variant of CYP19A1 was identified as a common polymorphism linked to aromatase activity. In assays, R264C had only 15% of aromatase activity when bound with WT-POR. Its activity was further reduced to nearly zero with P284L-POR and 6.7% with P284T-POR, indicating a significant impact on estrogen formation.
title: Differential effects of variations in human P450 oxidoreductase on the aromatase activity of CYP19A1 polymorphisms R264C and R264H

finding: The R264H variant of CYP19A1 was recognized as a rare variant that exhibited significantly higher aromatase activity (87%) when interacting with WT-POR. Notably, when paired with POR-Y607C, its activity increased more than three-fold compared to WT-CYP19A1, suggesting a positive interaction and beneficial effect on enzymatic activity.
title: Differential effects of variations in human P450 oxidoreductase on the aromatase activity of CYP19A1 polymorphisms R264C and R264H

finding: The study evaluated the causal SNP FURIN rs4702 and its association with schizophrenia (SCZ) by using hiPSC models combined with CRISPR gene editing technologies. It revealed genotype-dependent transcriptomic differences related to this SNP, which led to specific pre- and post-synaptic perturbations, indicating that rs4702 had a significant impact on gene expression and neuronal function in the context of schizophrenia.
title: Convergent impact of schizophrenia risk genes

finding: The SNP rs62013139 was found to be associated with allele-specific gains of methylation in cancer samples, specifically multiple myeloma, where it demonstrated significant hypermethylation differences between alleles.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: SLC24A5 (rs1426654), another locus associated with skin pigmentation, showed early selection, increasing in frequency prior to 3,500 years ago, based on the movement of northern populations.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The novel peak identified at SNP rs12594517 on chromosome 15 was characterized as significant within the African tracts of the dataset. Though its precise mechanism related to blood lipids was unclear, it was located near the genes MEIS2 and C15orf41, both associated with metabolic traits in earlier studies.
title: Tractor: A framework allowing for improved inclusion of admixed individuals in large-scale association studies

finding: The C allele at rs2289702 (C>T) was linked to increased expression of CTSH RNA across various tissues, suggesting a role in T1D susceptibility. The variant potentially enhanced sensitivity to viral infections, thereby raising the risk of early-diagnosed T1D in children.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: The SNP rs11070955 was positively associated with metabolic regulation of redox balance in cancer, particularly in the context of pancreatic cancer where its function was explored following PGC1a and PRC1 inhibition.
title: Integration of high-content fluorescence imaging into the metabolic flux assay reveals insights into mitochondrial properties and functions

finding: The SNP rs7163757 was highlighted as the likely causal variant for type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk at the VPS13C/C2CD4A/C2CD4B locus based on fine mapping studies. The investigation revealed that CRISPR manipulations at this site exerted significant effects on neighboring gene expressions, establishing it as an effector variant related to glucose metabolism and diabetes risk.
title: Sexually dimorphic roles for the type 2 diabetes-associated C2cd4b gene in murine glucose homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs7172432 demonstrated a statistically significant association (p=0.004) with waist circumference, which correlated with body weight changes observed in male C2cd4b knockout mice. Importantly, rs7172432 was found to be in perfect linkage disequilibrium (R²=1.0) with rs7163757, thus suggesting that the genetic impacts on body weight might stem from this T2D-associated variant.
title: Sexually dimorphic roles for the type 2 diabetes-associated C2cd4b gene in murine glucose homeostasis

finding: The rs4924345:C allele was associated with positive effects on bilateral central sulcus mean depth and surface area, alongside negative effects on neighboring superior postcentral sulcus measures.
title: Genetic map of regional sulcal morphology in the human brain

finding: The research indicated that the SNP rs16971798 of NUSAP1 might have an epistatic genetic interaction with the presence of tau filaments. This finding highlighted the role of NUSAP1 as a microtubule-stabilizing protein, whose loss of function was observed to facilitate tau aggregation. Furthermore, NUSAP1 was downregulated in the brains of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients, suggesting a potential link between its dysfunction, nucleolar impairment, and the progression of tauopathies.
title: Genome-wide CRISPRi screening reveals regulators of Alzheimer’s tau pathology shared between exosomal and vesicle-free tau seeds

finding: The SNP rs7170151 was found to have significant enhancer activity in T-lymphoid Jurkat cells. It demonstrated a ~50% increase in activity when homozygous for the risk allele, thereby indicating its role in regulating RASGRP1 expression relevant to the autoimmune disease systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: SNP rs11631591 showed marked enhancer activity, significantly upregulating RASGRP1 in T-cells, thus contributing to SLE risk. Its risk allele primarily bound to hnRNP-K, which modulated RASGRP1 expression and downstream ERK/MAPK signaling pathways.
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: Associated with SNP rs11631591, rs7173565 demonstrated significant enhancer activity in Jurkat cells, corroborating its role in enhancing RASGRP1 expression, relevant to SLE susceptibility.
title: Mechanistic characterization of RASGRP1 variants identifies an hnRNP K-regulated transcriptional enhancer contributing to SLE susceptibility

finding: Another variant, rs55712458, provided highly significant evidence of association with four of six dyslexia traits and was the strongest signal across all analyses, remaining robust against adjustments for verbal IQ.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: The rs12594395 variant was located in the downstream region of CYP19A1 and was associated with significant dyslexia-related traits. It was also predicted to affect transcription factor binding, indicating a possible regulatory role.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: The rare allele of rs141853734 was significantly correlated with decreased performance in word analysis tasks, representing a significant finding in association with dyslexia phenotypes.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: Variant rs2301249 was also associated with a decreased binding affinity for GATA4, as demonstrated in functional assays. It showed significant correlation with decreased expression of the ULK3 and CSK genes in the left ventricle of the heart.
title: Cardiovascular Disease-Associated Non-Coding Variants Disrupt GATA4-DNA Binding and Regulatory Functions

finding: The SNP rs11071010 was identified as a significant genetic marker associated with lung-seeking metastases. The context of this finding relates to the research on metastatic nodules that influence vascular functions in lung disease, as outlined in the study by Stella et al. (2019). The study demonstrated that the presence of metastatic nodules could affect vascular transport functions significantly, impacting up to 4-5 alveoli away from the tumor.
title: Probing lung function at high spatiotemporal resolution using a novel crystal ribcage

finding: The A allele of the regulatory SNP rs1979905 was linked to increased expression of the CHRNA5 gene, which predicted significantly reduced β-amyloid load in the cortex. The combined analysis showed that CHRNA5 expression was mainly regulated by this SNP rather than by the coding SNP rs16969968.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to severity of amyloid pathology in aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The A allele of the missense SNP rs16969968 was associated with lower CHRNA5 expression and rendered chandelier interneurons more vulnerable to β-amyloid presence, exacerbating their loss in individuals with high amyloid pathology.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to severity of amyloid pathology in aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The well-studied SNP rs17293632 was associated with Crohn's disease and inflammatory bowel disease. It had strong evidence from the AP-1 family motif suggesting the minor allele T increased disease risk by reducing SMAD3 gene expression, which in turn affected the TGF-beta signaling pathway relevant to T cell activation and metabolism.
title: Annotating and prioritizing human non-coding variants with RegulomeDB

finding: This SNP was observed to have directional effects on phenotypes such as schizophrenia and various anthropometric traits, showing associations with pulmonary measures.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: The SNP rs2247233 was identified as a top SNP within the enhancer enh41216, which resides in a super-enhancer (SE) associated with schizophrenia (SCZ). This locus included 12 transcribed enhancers (TEns) and 32 genes, but rs2247233 was specifically characterized as a causal transcript through FOCUS fine-mapping. The enhancer associated with this SNP contributed to explaining the genome-wide association study (GWAS) significance, indicating its crucial role in the heritability of schizophrenia.
title: Population-level variation of enhancer expression identifies novel disease mechanisms in the human brain

finding: The missense variant rs1048661 in the LOXL1 gene was associated with an increased risk of developing exfoliation syndrome (XFS). It was observed that this variant has a high degree of heterogeneity across different populations, with evidence of an effect reversal for the allele.
title: Analysis of Genetically Determined Gene Expression Suggests Role of Inflammatory Processes in Exfoliation Syndrome

finding: The missense variant rs3825942, also located in the LOXL1 gene, conferred risk for XFS, similarly demonstrating significant population heterogeneity and effect reversal in diverse cohorts.
title: Analysis of Genetically Determined Gene Expression Suggests Role of Inflammatory Processes in Exfoliation Syndrome

finding: The allelic variant rs1051168 was confirmed to regulate NMB gene expression in progenitor cells, with a significant association (p-value: 2.78e-09) identified through colocalization with the SCZ index SNP rs12908161, indicating a specific regulatory mechanism related to schizophrenia risk.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: The second strongest signal arose from the allele rs11636232 within OCA2/HERC2, which is recognized as a primary determinant of light eye color in European populations.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: The study found that individuals with the genotype rs12913832:GG were associated with brown eye color, indicating a genetic link to pigmentation traits. This SNP was studied in relation to SNPs in the TYR, TYRP1, and SLC24A4 genes, further supporting its role in influencing eye color.
title: Assessing and mitigating privacy risk of sparse, noisy genotypes by local alignment to haplotype databases

finding: For SNP rs12917011 located in 15q23, it was linked to osteoporosis (P<sub>GWAS</sub> = 2.1E-06) and correlated with the gene <italic>SPESP1</italic> (P<sub>TWAS</sub> = 3.3E-8), indicating its potential involvement in disease mechanisms.
title: Integrating genome-wide association and transcriptome predicted model identify novel target genes with osteoporosis

finding: This missense variant of OCA2 (c.913C>T or p.Arg305Trp) was identified in albino individuals and was associated with albinism, contributing to pigmentation loss.
title: Native American Ancestry and Pigmentation Allele Contributions to Skin Color in a Caribbean Population

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was identified as a significant variant affecting the blue eye color phenotype. It was located in a region with a strong excess IBD rate, which was thirty-five standard deviations above the population median. The additive selection coefficient for this SNP was estimated at 0.0225 (95% CI = (0.0196, 0.0254)), indicating substantial selection pressure acting on this variant in recent generations.
title: Modeling recent positive selection in Americans of European ancestry

finding: The SNP rs17514846 was associated with differential Fes protein levels, where carriers of this SNP had lower levels of Fes, which correlated with a reduced cancer incidence (HR 1.03, p=0.01) and decreased risk of death (HR 1.06, p=0.03) in a large cohort from the United Kingdom Biobank comprising over 400,000 individuals. This finding underscored the potential role of Fes as a modifier of cancer susceptibility, suggesting that lower Fes levels could contribute to a delay in tumor initiation and improve survival outcomes.
title: Fes-deficient macrophages enhance CD8+ T cell priming and tumour control through increased proinflammatory cytokine production and presentation

finding: The SNP rs4932196 was associated with self-reported hearing difficulty in the UK Biobank cohort, showing a genome-wide significant association (p = 2.6e-5). This finding was notable as it represented both a positive finding and an original report of significance within this larger dataset.
title: Biological insights from multi-omic analysis of 31 genomic risk loci for adult hearing difficulty

finding: The SNP rs4702, located in the 3' UTR of the FURIN gene, was found to significantly impact SARS-CoV-2 infectivity. Specifically, allelic conversion from AA to GG led to decreased FURIN mRNA levels, reduced neuronal outgrowth, and altered activity in glutamatergic neurons, indicating that rs4702 genotype influences the expression of FURIN, a key mediator of viral entry. In vitro studies demonstrated that the GG genotype exhibited lower FURIN expression and correspondingly reduced viral infection rates in alveolospheres and neurons compared to the AA genotype.
title: Common genetic variation in humans impacts in vitro susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: The Neanderthal variant rs950169 in ADAMTSL3 resulted in a truncated protein. It was identified as an allele-specific expression variant, with SpliceAI predicting the loss of the upstream acceptor.
title: Resurrecting the Alternative Splicing Landscape of Archaic Hominins using Machine Learning

finding: The non-synonymous polymorphism rs16969968 (D398N) in the Chrna5 gene was associated with nicotine dependence, schizophrenia, and cognitive impairment. Additionally, nicotinic α4β2α5 receptors with the D398N polymorphism exhibited a partial loss of function due to alterations in receptor desensitization, calcium permeability, or membrane trafficking.
title: Chrna5 is a marker of acetylcholine super-responder subplate neurons with specialized expression of nicotinic modulator proteins

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was associated with the modulation of human pigmentation. It was specifically noted for its role in attenuating chromatin-loop formation between a long-range enhancer and the OCA2 promoter, which is significant in the context of pigmentation traits.
title: LungCancer3D: A Comprehensive Database for Integrating Lung Cancer Chromatin Architecture with Other Multi-omics

finding: The SNP rs3212335, an intronic variant in the GABRB3 gene, passed the Bonferroni-corrected p-value threshold with a p-value of 7e-6, indicating a maternal genetic effect on offspring birthweight. This finding is significant as GABRB3 is crucial for neurodevelopment and exhibits parent-of-origin imprinting effects.
title: Modeling Parent-Specific Genetic Nurture in Families with Missing Parental Genotypes: Application to Birthweight and BMI

finding: The non-synonymous rs16969968 (D398N) polymorphism in Chrna5 was associated with nicotine dependence, schizophrenia, and cognitive impairment. The polymorphism resulted in nicotinic α4β2α5 receptors exhibiting partial loss of function, which was attributed to alterations in receptor desensitization, calcium permeability, or membrane trafficking.
title: Chrna5 and lynx prototoxins identify acetylcholine super-responder subplate neurons

finding: The SNP rs11070948 was associated with changes in SCD1 activity, which in turn related to inflammation and stress responses in cells. This finding highlighted the potential role of SCD1 in cancer and metabolic syndrome, emphasizing the significance of SCD1 as a therapeutic target. The analysis suggested that variations in this SNP could influence individual susceptibility to diseases linked to altered fatty acid metabolism.
title: Sequential dynamics of Stearoyl-CoA Desaturase-1(SCD1) /ligand binding and unbinding mechanism: A computational study

finding: The association between SNP rs372754794 and variation in L cone ratios was identified as significant (p-value=1.67 x 10^-5). This SNP resides within an intron of the non-coding RNA NR2F2-AS1, upstream of the NR2F2 gene, and the G allele was linked to a reduced L cone ratio, predominantly found in African American and African populations.
title: Spatiotemporal specification of green and red cones in human retinas and organoids

finding: The SNP rs2652822 was linked with plasma succinylcarnitine levels in a large analysis of two European population-based cohorts. The strength of this association was indicated by a very low p-value of 7×10<sup>-27</sup>.
title: High Throughput Computational Mouse Genetic Analysis

finding: The study demonstrated that the rs12913832 SNP was highly associated with the eye color phenotype. In the analysis of a dataset comprising 1925 Estonian individuals, it was found that nearly 96% of individuals with at least one ancestral allele (A) presented brown eye color, whereas 80% of the artificial genomes (GAN AGs) exhibited this trait. Additionally, 97% of blue-eyed individuals in the real dataset and 88% in the AGs were homozygous for the derived allele (G). No blue-eyed individuals from the real dataset were homozygous for the ancestral allele, with only 9 blue-eyed GAN AG individuals being homozygous ancestral, highlighting the ability of AGs to replicate existing genotype-phenotype associations.
title: Creating Artificial Human Genomes Using Generative Models

finding: It was identified as a strong aseQTL for ADAM10 in the TC region, showcasing its regional expression characteristics.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs11070952 was found to have a significant impact on the outcomes of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients treated with lenvatinib, particularly in relation to the baseline ALBI grade, which indicates liver function. The study showed that patients with a better liver functional reserve, as indicated by the ALBI score, had higher objective response rates (ORR) and longer overall survival (OS) when treated with lenvatinib.
title: Therapeutic Efficacy and Safety of Lenvatinib for Unresectable Hepatocellular Carcinoma Beyond Progression with Sorafenib

finding: The rs77004004 variant within the ATP8B4 gene was classified as damaging and was one of the variants associated with the identified mutation burden in the Botswana population.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing-based Characterization of Human Genome Variation and Mutation Burden in Botswana

finding: The SNP rs11070948 was linked to the dysregulation of stearoyl CoA desaturase 1 (SCD1), an enzyme implicated in altered monounsaturated fatty acid metabolism in cancer. This SNP's association provided novel insights into the role of cVA in regulating prostate cancer cell viability, marking a significant finding in the context of oncogenic transformation.
title: Cis-vaccenic acid is a key product of stearoyl-CoA desaturase 1 and a critical oncogenic factor in prostate cancer

finding: This SNP showed a genome-wide significant association with imaging phenotypes, further evaluated for its potential functional impacts.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12050604 showed a significant association with a low p value of 5.08 × 10^-7 and also influenced the significance of nearby SNPs when conditioned upon.
title: BayesRB: a markov chain Monte Carlo-based polygenic genetic risk score algorithm for dichotomous traits

finding: The rs200342067 SNP located in the FBN1 gene was identified as a population-specific missense variant associated with lower height in the Peruvian population. Each copy of the minor allele (C) reduced height by 2.2 cm in heterozygous individuals, with homozygous individuals experiencing a reduction of 4.4 cm. This finding was significant, with a minor allele frequency of 4.7% and a p-value of 8.0×10^-10, marking it as the largest effect size known for a common height-associated variant.
title: A positively selected, common, missense variant in FBN1 confers a 2.2 centimeter reduction of height in the Peruvian population

finding: The A allele of the regulatory SNP rs1979905 was significantly associated with higher expression of the CHRNA5 gene (t = 27.47, p = 5.36*10^-121) and linked to reduced β-amyloid load in the brain (t = -2.81, pFDR = 0.015) in a study involving aging and Alzheimer’s disease.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to protection against amyloid pathology in human aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The A allele of the missense SNP rs16969968 was associated with lower CHRNA5 expression (t = -13.61, p = 1.63*10^-38) and was found to render chandelier interneurons more vulnerable to increased β-amyloid levels (interaction term t = -2.842, p = 0.005), suggesting it impacts nicotinic receptor functionality.
title: CHRNA5 links chandelier cells to protection against amyloid pathology in human aging and Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs2568494, located in the IREB2 gene, was associated with an increased risk of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) as indicated in a meta-analysis conducted by Du et al. in 2016. This finding highlighted the genetic contribution of IREB2 polymorphisms to the susceptibility of developing COPD.
title: Fibroblast-derived Osteoglycin Promotes Epithelial Cell Repair

finding: This SNP was found within the <italic>CHRNA5</italic> gene and was recognized as a known schizophrenia variant in humans, suggesting its involvement in the genetic risk of the disorder.
title: Evolutionary constraint genes implicated in autism spectrum disorder across 2,054 nonhuman primate genomes

finding: The rs492571 SNP was found to create a new start codon in the 5’UTR of the NM_001286491.2 isoform, resulting in a fully upstream open reading frame (uORF) that included 34 amino acids. This variant was situated within a locus associated with triglycerides and HDL-cholesterol levels, suggesting its potential role in explaining GWAS signals related to lipid metabolism.
title: MORFEE: a new tool for detecting and annotating single nucleotide variants creating premature ATG codons from VCF files

finding: At the rs1426654 locus, selection occurred early for skin pigmentation alleles with frequencies rising to near fixation by approximately 3,500 years ago in groups moving northwards and westwards.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The OCA2 rs1800414 T/C SNP was associated with signals of positive natural selection in East Asian populations, particularly linked to light skin color and tanning ability. Its frequency began to increase around 25,000 years ago, potentially related to vitamin D synthesis in low sunlight regions.
title: Exploring the genetic diversity of the Japanese Population: Insights from a Large-Scale Whole Genome Sequencing Analysis

finding: SNP rs8040334 was associated with the discrimination of invasive species within Mediterranean ecosystems. Its positive identification indicated a potential for ecological management and restoration strategies.
title: Scientific opportunities for developing essential biodiversity variables from satellite remote sensing in the context of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework

finding: The SNP rs12913832 was highly associated with eye color, where nearly 96% of individuals with at least one ancestral allele A had brown eyes. The generative models created artificial genomes (AGs) that reproduced this phenotypic-genotypic association with an 80% accuracy for allele A. Additionally, 97% of blue-eyed individuals had both derived alleles (G) in the real dataset, and this was closely mirrored by an 88% ratio in the AGs, although 9 individuals in the AGs were found to carry both ancestral alleles, which did not exist in the real dataset.
title: Creating Artificial Human Genomes Using Generative Models

finding: The germline variant rs34988193 found in the tumor suppressor gene ANKDD1a led to an amino acid change and was predictive of poor prognosis in low grade glioma patients. This variant was observed to be significantly deleterious, boasting a hazard ratio of 1.73 in TCGA and 1.79 in CGGA datasets, indicating poor outcomes across different populations.
title: The Germline Variants rs61757955 and rs34988193 are Predictive of Survival in Low Grade Glioma Patients

finding: The SNP rs7163757 was associated with chromatin accessibility at the C2CD4A/B locus, which colocalized with T2D GWAS signals. The T (non-risk) allele was linked to higher chromatin accessibility, suggesting a regulatory role influencing genetic risk for T2D through the VPS13C gene.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: The SNP rs7162757 was noted for its association with a caPeak, having direct implications for chromatin accessibility linked to the expression of nearby genes, particularly under conditions relevant to T2D.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: For SNP rs12901372, similar to rs10502437, there was evidence of colocalisation between GWAS signals and low-grade cartilage molecular QTLs, suggesting that the risk allele was also linked to increased gene expression. This further emphasizes the relevance of this SNP in understanding osteoarthritis pathology.
title: Decoding the genomic basis of osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12915901 was identified as a key target variant within the osteoarthritis genetic risk at the ALDH1A2 locus. It was functionally characterized and its association with osteoarthritis suggestive of its critical role in the disease mechanisms.
title: Decoding the genomic basis of osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs12913832 near HERC2 displayed strong evidence of selection, corroborating its role in pigmentation differences.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: Evidence of selection for the light allele of rs1635168 near HERC2 was noted, highlighting its association with skin pigmentation.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs4778123 near OCA2 was observed to show changes in frequency consistent with changes in genome-wide ancestry rather than direct selection.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: Evidence for rs2675345 at SLC24A5 showed change in allele frequencies driven by both ancestry and time, and selection continued post-admixture following the light allele's introduction.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The rs9920172 at the OCA2 locus exhibited heightened PBS signals, particularly in hunter-gatherers, supporting a historical pattern of selection in pigmentation.
title: The evolution of skin pigmentation associated variation in West Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs15342, which represented a T to C change at chr15:101070089, disrupted a strong hexamer AATAAA associated with an annotated poly(A) site located 22 nucleotides downstream. This modification led to a significant difference in transcript structure, producing a poly(A) tail for the wildtype transcript while the variant transcript lacked it. Consequently, this SNP is associated with a longer 3' UTR that contains numerous miRNA binding sites and extensive RBP sites for 77 RBPs. Termin(A)n tor classified the wildtype and variant transcripts with probabilities of 0.98 and 0.01, respectively.
title: Termin(A)ntor: Polyadenylation Site Prediction Using Deep Learning Models

finding: The SNP rs2470102 was positively associated with skin colour variation in Indian populations. It was located in a predicted target site for miR-1180-3p in the MYEF2 gene, which has an unclear functional relationship with skin colour. The analysis revealed a strong association between the frequency of the target allele and absolute latitude, suggesting a selective pressure in populations with less UV exposure to lose the target site.
title: Pervasive selection against microRNA target sites in human populations

finding: The rs6224 SNP was associated with schizophrenia at genome-wide significance (P < 5×10<sup>−8</sup>), indicating that alleles increasing the odds of left-handedness also increased the risk of schizophrenia.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 49 common genetic variants associated with handedness

finding: The study reported that the rs762551 SNP directly influenced caffeine metabolism, revealing that among the LSSU student population, there were 42.7% fast, 44.5% medium, and 12.8% slow metabolizers. The data supported the initial hypothesis, indicating that these frequencies were representative of the general population's allele distribution.
title: Analysis of the CYP1A2 caffeine metabolism gene in the student population at Lake Superior State University

finding: The SNP rs1426654 was found to influence skin pigmentation, where its reference allele was associated with light skin color commonly observed in individuals of West Eurasian ancestry. The investigation through the human pangenome identified a perfect match for the reference allele and a mismatch for the variant allele on exon 3 of the SLC24A5 gene on chromosome 15. When searching exclusively within the European core genome, only the reference allele was found, which confirmed previous study findings.
title: Detecting High Scoring Local Alignments in Pangenome Graphs

finding: The SNP rs1800401 was identified as a missense variant (c.913C>T or p.Arg305Trp) in the OCA2 gene, which was implicated in the phenotype of oculocutaneous albinism. The context indicated that it was one of the 12 variant alleles identified through whole exome sequencing in an albino individual, demonstrating a direct link to this condition.
title: Effects of Ancestry and Hypopigmenting Alleles on Skin Color in a Caribbean Native American Population

finding: Moderate evidence of selection was found for rs12913832 related to the OCA2/HERC2 gene, with an estimated selection coefficient (s) of approximately 0.002. This SNP is known for its association with eye color and showed high differentiation across populations, indicating early selection may have begun around 50,000 years ago.
title: An approximate full-likelihood method for inferring selection and allele frequency trajectories from DNA sequence data

finding: The C allele at rs2289702 (C>T) was associated with increased expression of CTSH mRNA in multiple cell types and tissues. This variant was linked to altered sensitivity of beta cells to apoptosis, suggesting that the type 1 diabetes risk allele may lead to increased susceptibility to viral infections due to elevated TLR3 functionality, which could explain the earlier onset of type 1 diabetes in children.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: The rs3825932 (C>T) variant was investigated as it showed low linkage disequilibrium (LD) with disease-associated variants. The findings indicated that this variant counter-intuitively resulted in protection from beta-cell apoptosis, suggesting that beta-cell apoptosis may not be the primary mechanism of type 1 diabetes aetiology in this region.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: The study found that individuals homozygous for the rs17514846 SNP, which was associated with a 50% reduction in FES expression, had increased cancer incidence rates in the UK Biobank cohort (Hazard Ratio 1.03, p=0.01) and higher risk of death (Hazard Ratio 1.06, p=0.03). This correlation suggested that lower Fes expression associated with the SNP could be linked to delayed tumour onset and changes in immune response, thus playing a significant role in cancer progression.
title: Fes-deficient macrophages enhance CD8+ T cell priming and tumour control through increased pro-inflammatory cytokine production and localization

finding: The SNP rs1426654 was identified as a non-synonymous mutation associated with skin pigmentation. It was fixed in European descendants, presenting a high F<sub>ST</sub> value of 0.985 between CEU (Utah residents with Northern and Western European ancestry) and YRI (Yoruba in Ibadan, Nigeria).
